When my granddaughters saw this, they screamed at the top of their lungs! They were super excited. They have quite a collection of Barbies but no Barbie automobiles. Now they have this wonderful Barbie Camper and they love it. This is a big camper and there is a lot to do when camping. With three stories, there is a slide that runs from the second story and into your very own swimming pool. The top pops up and you can put your little table and chairs up there and eat in style. Turn the spare tire over and you have a hidden fire pit. It has a kitchen, a bathroom, a family room and more. It's like Barbie meets transformers. Flips the steering wheel to reveal a sink and much more wonderful hidden goodies. Just finding everything was an adventure for the kids.

This Barbie camper is well made and has so much fantabulousness about it. We are over the moon happy with it.

It seems these days so many building and design type toys are made for boys so I was super excited to find Design and Drill Dazzling Creations for my five year old daughter Paige to try!

This cute set comes with the following:

Multilingual package and instructions in English, Spanish, French, and German
1 Ratcheting screwdriver with forward and reverse switch
Star-shaped bit
4 Mini fun-shaped activity boards: castle, unicorn, crown, and dress
30 Translucent, sparkly bolts
8 Clear faceted gem caps

Paige was so excited to get started right away, and so were her brothers! Her older brother Reed read her the directions while she followed them: teamwork at it's best!

The four main boards are shapes all girls adore. Paige's favorite was the castle since she loves all things princess! These two had a lot of fun working on them together.

At five and seven they were able to do this completely on their own with no help from mommy so that was a nice change! It's designed for ages 4+ because of small parts little ones could choke on and the muscle coordination it takes to use the screwdriver. That didn't stop my one and a half year old from trying for himself, completely supervised of course!

I thought it was cute how these were like real tools but sparkly and girly, and made for kids of course! They are really good quality and I don't see any of the parts ever breaking.

All three of my kids have had a great time playing with this one and it does my heart good to see them working together and liking the same thing, even if it is "girlie" and two of my three kids are boys!

From working on their motor skills and coordination to sorting and colors; this set is educational AND fun. You really can have it all with Design & Drill and while it may be for girls, trust me when I say the boys will dig it too!

My 8 year-old daughter has several Baby Alive dolls, and this is one of her favorites! The doll is a classic "drink and wet" style baby doll... give her a sip of water from a sippy-top teacup and she wets her diaper. Simple but timeless! I think this doll, which has brown hair and green eyes, is very pretty, and my brown-haired daughter LOVES that it looks more like her than all the blond-haired, blue-eyed ones we have.

This doll wears an adorable little dress, a tiara, and a disposable diaper, and comes with her sippy cup plus a teapot and cup to let your child join in the tea party. The only negative with this set is the disposable diaper, which - guess what? - only lasts for the first two minutes out of the box. I wish this doll came with a padded cloth diaper that could be dried out and reused, but since she doesn't, we use some reusable cloth diapers that we found at Target or sit Baby naked on our toy potty seat while we give her a drink. Works for us!

Very fun, light-middle weight game that is really about getting the most points. To do that, you use worker placement to collect resources (food, cards, and dice) and then you fight a variety of pesky monsters using those resources. This isn't a deeply strategic game, so don't expect that or you will be disappointed. Decisions are around worker placement and also which dice and how many dice you want to use to fight the monsters, as some limit what you can use. Players also have secret goals that they are trying to accomplish for end-game scoring. I really like heavier board games, but when you don't want to hurt your brain, this is a great time.

reviewText: These were the hit of my child's party.  Even the adults took some home to play with!

These are the cards that I wish came with the original game purchase.  They are the size of regulation playing cards and make them much easier to shuffle and hold.

In addition to the new card size though, this expansion added some complexity to a game that my wife and I have been playing for a few years.  New routes meant we had to look for new strategies to make them and in some cases the cards contain a challenge of having to route through a large city, making it even more difficult.

I have found that Ticket to Ride expansions are great and are well worth the money for the most part, but this one in particular is almost a must have even if you are just purchasing the game.

Ticket to Ride was our first time getting out of standard board games and has driven us to try other table top games that provide many hours of game play and are far more interesting than the standard monopoly type games (and typically cause far fewer tantrums).
summary: This Should Come with The Standard Game

reviewText:
This is the nicest Air Hogs plane we have had by far.  The flight time on one charge is longer than the (probably about 15) other planes and helicopters that we have tried.  The plane crashed several times but was not damaged.  The plane/helicopter arrived charged and we flew it for about 20 minutes on the charge.  When the helicopter started losing height we recharged it for about 15 minutes and it flew for another about 15 - 20 minutes
When hovering as a helicopter you are not able to move the device beyond spinning it so that it is facing the direction in which you would like it to fly.  The transformation takes place quickly when a button is pressed and when flying as a plane it is easy to control and maneuvers very nicely.  We were flying in a little bit of wind and it was much easier to control than our HobbyZone Scout is in very calm weather.  You can then convert back into a helicopter for landing by pressing the button again.
We received the plane to test and evaluate and it really exceeded our expectations. After the first two flight sessions my husband, son and I tried to guess what the price would be and the lowest guess was $99.  We were surprised when we looked up the actual price.  From a parents perspective this helicopter/plane is a huge improvement from the Air Hogs helicopters and planes we have had in the past.  The engineering and construction is very nicely done in comparison.  It is made of a foam that is like Styrofoam but much stronger and more flexible.  We have had about 5 other Air Hogs helicopters, which did not hold a charge as well, took a long time to charge and broke easily (and often with the first crash or two).  Our son loves helicopters and planes but we have had a hard time finding something for him to fly that he can control and is sturdy enough to get through the learning phase.  The fact that the battery charges quickly is great when you have an impatient and excited child.  So far we are very impressed by this device.
My 12 year olds review: This is really amazing and cool and awesome and I would really like to have more of them.  They fly well and the takeoff works nicely.  The transformation of the wings is very fast and the steering works well for the weight of the plane.
summary: Great choice for our 12 year old

reviewText: Smaller than I thought but grandson will love it on Christmas

Although iTrax is recommended for ages 6 and up, we've played this as a family with my 4-year-old and even my 2-year-old enjoys taking part (he'll build little towers or try to copy us).  The game includes enough pieces for up to 4 players to play at the same time, as well as game cards with patterns that range from easy to very difficult. I gave my daughter the easiest cards to start out with but she quickly caught on and moved up through the cards.  The object of the game is to find which pattern on the card is connected by the two small blocks and duplicate it exactly - it's a race to see who can duplicate their card first.  The patterns are true to size so if Emma is unsure which length is correct she can lay the rod directly on the card to be sure it's the right one.

When we play together my husband and I take the hardest cards and give my daughter the easier ones, we count down to 0 and then GO!  It's a race to see who can find and duplicate their pattern first.  It's truly a blast!  I recommend this game - it has quickly become a family favorite because it is easy to pull out and play a few games then put away.  Because the pieces are small, it doesn't take up too much space, either.  Another plus is that it's challenging and enjoyable enough for kids to want to play by themselves.  :)
(This game was sent to me for review purposes)
summary: My 4-year-old gives this one two thumbs up, and so do I!

reviewText:
My 6-year-old daughter wanted to try out this car. We put in the (three AAA) batteries and charged it for 20 seconds, then let it go, and... it was really unimpressive. "Nonstop stunt action?" Hardly. But then I thought that maybe the batteries weren't as fresh as they could be. I changed to three new ones, and ZOOM! The motorcycle took off across the room and cracked us up. It was the little motorcycle that could. It rode over the rug, smacked into the door and rebounded, and all-around went crazy for 20 seconds. (We timed it a couple of times.) It's fast and funny action while it lasts, but it really does just last 20 seconds. Then it slows way down and comes to a complete stop around 40 seconds, and you have to charge it again. That gets tedious.

The other problem is that my daughter has a hard time lining up the little tab on the motorcycle bottom with the slot on the charger. It's tiny and requires decent motor skills to get it lined up.

So it's a novel way to charge rather than the "roll-back and go" method, and it kind of looks like a crazy rodent when it's bumping around and rebounding all over the place, but three batteries is a bit much and the charging method is not my favorite.

if you need small, flat starfish, these are perfect. I won't give a bad review, because it was my fault i didn't read very well (lol).

while these are very cute, they are smaller than I anticipated- between 1-2 inches at the MOST (and i think only one is 2"). I see that now in the description. they did arrive very quickly and packaged well (very good since they are quite fragile.). Although this DVD game of "Who Wants To Be a Millionaire" is very fun and much like the show, it has several aspects of it that were not well thought out by the creators.

First of all, the game was not intended for a solo player; it was meant for 2-4 players, but it is possible to work around this.  Each player is given six cards that say: A, B, C, D, Walk Away, or have the pictures of all the lifelines.  The player is then supposed to select the card that they wish to use based on the question.  Now, the questions don't stay up for long, rather they come up for maybe 20 seconds then they go away.  The question is read to you, though, so if you have trouble reading, this does make it easier to play the game.  After the question has been read, you are then asked if anyone chose to use a lifeline.  The problem with this is that only one player can use a lifeline per question.  Now, he can use more than one of his lifelines, but if more than one person wanted to use a lifeline, the second person is going to be out of luck.  The lifelines available in this game are 50:50, Ask the Audience, and Phone a Friend.  After the lifelines are used (or not) you are then told the answer to the question and asked if anyone got it wrong.  And after that question you have to answer the question of whether someone walked away.  Although these questions are vital to the gameplay, they slow it down and you are forced to answer them each question. There are a lot of questions in the game, though, and I have rarely had a repeat question in playing this game.  The questions range in difficulty from easy to hard, so there is a nice variety.  There is also variety in the styles of questions, they range from knitting questions to geography questions.

Overall, this is a fun game to play with friends, but it has its tedious moments.  If you're willing to spend a large portion of the game answering whether players used lifelines or walked away then it can be quite an entertaining play.
summary: It wasn't thought all the way through before it was sold.

reviewText:
The one-step changers line of figures is pretty much as advertised -- figures that only require one movement to transform them from robot mode to vehicle mode.  This makes them best for young kids, who probably don't have the patience or hand-eye coordination for a complex transformation process and want something quick and simple.  Older collectors, meanwhile, will probably be annoyed at the simplicity of these figures, and prefer the larger, more complex figures.

I purchased the Grimlock one-step changer because I simply wanted an inexpensive figure of one of my favorite Transformer characters.  In this case, I find myself wishing I'd splurged on the larger figure instead.  Grimlock is TOO simple, and even at nine dollars is still too expensive for what you get.

One-Step Grimlock feels more like a glorified McDonald's Happy Meal toy than a true Transformers figure.  The plastic he's made of feels cheap, and he lacks any sort of movable joints.  I like figures that are at least somewhat posable, so to have what basically amounts to a statue instead of an action figure feels like a cheat.  His transformation basically consists of folding his legs back -- though his robot mode leaves a lot to be desired, so he'll probably be staying in dino mode on my shelf.

I understand the one-step changers were made with kids in mind, but I get the feeling that even young children will quickly grow bored with a toy that can't be posed and has a single gimmick in place of an actual transformation.  And the fact that he costs anywhere from seven to ten dollars (depending on where you buy him) feels like a ripoff.  Save your money for the full-size figure.
summary: Overpriced for what you get -- best for young children

reviewText:
My four year old boy, who is behind in development and doesn't care for toys, played with the ball popper for SIX HOURS straight on his birthday.  His six year old brother tried to play it whenever he could, and I spent all day keeping him away.  Later he played with it by the hour.

The only draw back is, I totally lost my concentration that day, listening to the music plus fan blowing all day long.  How much do you like The Flight of the Bumble Bee?  To me, it sound as annoying as a real bee buzzing around after I heard it 100 times in a day! It was worth it, though, seeing my kids so happy!  (I could have gone to a different room, of course, but I didn't think of it until my brain was numb.)

It takes 4 DD batteries, and so far it has run 20 hours without needing to change battery. I really like the design of having the fan run only for a while after the baby smacks the switch.  Then it stops until the baby hits the switch again, so it really saves on batteries.

Lovely toy, don't hesitate to buy it now!

And thanks so much, Fisher Price!

My kids love this series.  If you're a fan of Imaginext, this is a good 2-pack if you can get it at a reasonable price (I found it for $6.99 at Target).

Darkseid is well-represented here.  Nice detail for this size.  Good quality, just like basically all of the other DC Imaginext figures.

The Superman is the New 52 uniform, very similar to the one in the 2-pack with Wonder Woman.  This version has lighter reds (actually more of a "regular" red, vs the other one's darker red), and the "S" chest logo is a little more classic and comic-like (the other one has some black outlining, looks a little more "formal" if that makes any sense).  Nice cape.

Recommended if you really want Darkseid, otherwise not worth the purchase if you already have the other New 52 Superman.  I'm docking this item one star because I'm annoyed that Fischer-Price is repackaging specific characters in 2-packs, requiring people to get repeats of individual characters if they want to get at least one version of others.  Since Superman is already available with Wonder Woman, why couldn't they have packaged someone unique with Darkseid?  And of the "repeats," this (Superman) is the least essential.

reviewText: This is a wonderful High Grade. All of Bandai's 2013+ kits are very detailed and articulated. You can get 90 degree or more bends out of the knee and elbow joints, which are double jointed. My 2 big complaints are 1: the decals are just stickers, not dry transfers or waterslides, so they will never look as good because of their outline. And 2 the ammo packs on the side skirts are not removeable for some reason, even though it would be very easy to do so, since the kit has two beam sabers with are stored inside of panels that are removeable on both sides of the calves. This kit comes with great color separation and colored stickers for parts that need to be painted, but I really recommend getting your hands dirty and painting this because it is such a wonderfully detailed kit. It has detail in parts that are not even seen, like Master Grade kits.
summary: Highly detailed, very articulated. Some parts don't make sense, recommend painting

Like some other reviewers mention, the Ker Plunk game here is an updated version of a classic game beloved by my parents and myself as children. My husband and I were eager to introduce this game to our 5-year-old and thought it would be a fun game to play with as a family. We did have fun, but the two adults (me and hubby) found the shoddy construction particularly deplorable.

Basically, the game parts consist of two plastic tubes with a plastic connector in between. These three parts are to be manually attached together and stood on the game base which is also made of plastic. The plastic color sticks are then to be inserted through the little holes in the tube connector in a crisscross pattern which will serve to hold the marbles ( which are provided in the box).

The problems with this game are mainly due to the cheap plastic parts - they are so insubstantial and moving the canister (for each player's turn) is cumbersome as a result and inadvertently jolts the marbles even further. Luckily, my 5-year-old was patient enough with the careful manipulation during each player's turn, and we did have fun, but we found the overall experience to be underwhelming.
summary: Shoddy construction, though the game itself is fun

reviewText:
I really really love this mess-free doll and so does my little girl (2.5 years old).  Please check out the videos on youtube on how this doll actually works, because when I've mentioned it to others, they assume it is the doll that wets and poops her diapers, requiring the special (pricey) diapers and baby food.  This doll DOES NOT pee, DOES NOT poop, and DOES NOT require special food or diapers which is why I love her.  This doll is very fun, totally functional, and completely clean!

Doll comes with 1) 2 piece outfit; 2) "magic bananas" spoon; 3) "magic bananas" spoon; and 4) apple juice sippy cup (which does not actually drip juice from it but does give the appearance that the juice is disappearing during feeding.  The doll speaks when he tongue is activated by either the sippy cup or spoon and she says a large variety of adorable phrases.  She also speaks when you press her bracelet.

The best feature of this doll is how she eats her food (and why I recommend viewing a video of this).  When you place the spoon into the bowl, it "magically" fills up with yummy (plastic) bananas thanks to a tiny trigger on the back of the spoon which is triggered by the bowl.  When you bring the spoon to the dolls lips, the trigger is again activated and the food "disappears" giving the appearance that the doll has eaten the bananas.  I was concerned my 2.5 year old would have difficulties feeding the doll and filling the spoon in the manner needed to trigger the features, but she has had no trouble at all and thinks it's pretty amazing...as do I!

I highly recommend this doll :)
summary: Love this doll!  Adorable and mess-free!

"Madame Alexander" is one of many similar knockoff brands that are currently competing to fill the lower cost market share of the much higher quality/cost American Girl dolls (like this one for instance - American Girl McKenna Doll and Book Doll. My daughters have several of the lower cost dolls including this one from Madame Alexander (Madame Alexander 18" Hangin' with Friends) and this one from "Our Generation" (Our Generation Ashley-Rose and the dolls are of similar quality and cost ($40-$50). Specifically about the "My Little Sweetheart" doll, my five year old daughter absolutely loved it as it has long blond hair just like she does and she also like the clothes (which completely come off revealing brown cloth underneath that gives a "pajama-type" appearance). The face of the doll is very pretty and the hair is soft. The clothing is not cheap in appearance or wear. Of course my dughter pulled bow out of the doll's hair 2 hrs after she opened it and it's impossible to get back on... After cutting the stitching, we were able to simple just tie it back on. However, any expecting this doll to be exactly the same as an "American Doll" is sorely mistaken. You can't pay $45 for a doll and expect it to be exactly the same as one that cost at least $150. That being said, the Madame Alexander doll is a nice brand and gives great quality at an affordable price.
summary: Great Doll For The Price - Very Beautiful

The objective is to putt the ball into the little gator's mouth, and each time a putt is successful, the gator returns it with a swish of its tail! The first player to get four points wins the game. This is a great game for counting [the number of putts], improving coordination, building concentration skills and of course, just plain simple fun.

I highly recommend this delightful game for little ones aged 3-5. A value buy for what you get!

This kit is even better then the Starry Night Kit -- it's fun to have both. Only one child can use the kit at a time, but the plastic stencils are re-usable to infinity. The kit comes with two pieces of paper 16X20 -- if you have more children, you will need more paper. Each created painting resembles Vincent's Sunflowers, but each child adds their own touches, as well. Great Spring Break activity. Parent note: Takes a dedicated space for rolling out paint, placing used stencils, and letting the paintings dry -- plan ahead and save your newspapers. You don't want to start this on your kitchen table and then have no place to eat dinner, eh? Recommend these recent books on Van Gogh, and I recommend the "Starry Night" Master Kitz, too: Sunflowers and Swirly Stars Vincent Van Gogh: Sunflowers and Swirly Stars (Smart About Art) My Brother VincentMy Brother Vincent Van Gogh Master Kitz The Starry Night

reviewText:
I now have this version of Risk in addition to the older Halo Wars version. Both are awesome.

First of all, you should not buy this if you are not already familiar with the standard game of Risk and its rules. I feel like it could be much more confusing to learn all the original rules plus the extra rules this adds on top of it. You should also not buy this if you are not a Halo fan. It simply doesn't make sense. Half the fun of the game is recognizing various locations and unit models from the Halo universe. If you aren't familiar with that universe you'd be better served to get the standard Risk game (which is cheaper anyway). I wouldn't go buy a Kardashians Risk, for example, because I don't care about the Kardashians.

Okay, so now we've established the target demographic. You are already a fan of Risk and Halo. You will really like this game. But the question is will you prefer this game or Halo Wars Risk? If you are an ultra-Halo-nerd like me, you can get both. Otherwise, I would say it depends on how much you are willing to bend the original rules of Risk.

Halo Wars Risk has 3 races, Human (UNSC), Covenant, and Flood. It also adds the "hero" element to each team (Master Chief, Arbiter, etc), which gives you a slight edge on your dice rolls when your "hero" is in effect. But Halo Wars Risk has an identical map to the original Risk, except not. What I mean is, there is a perfect 1:1 mapping of the original Risk countries/continents/territories, but it has been completely restyled and rethemed to Halo. You would NEVER notice this if you weren't already a pretty big Risk nerd, since the continents to not resemble Earth's continents at all. Where it really reveals the similarities are the territory *borders*. In the south-east part of the game board, for example, you have a re-themed Australia, with only 3-4 territories and only one way in, worth an additional 2 units per turn when fully occupied. In the south-west is a re-themed South America, with 5-6 territories and two ways in (from North America and Africa), which is worth 3 additional units per turn. This ensures the well-thought-out and time-tested borders of the original Risk are preserved, without appearing to be the same game board.

Now this Halo Legendary version keeps the "hero" and "base" elements of Halo Wars Risk along with the same 3 races of game pieces, but it completely scraps those traditional borders and territory layout. There are two physical game boards, each with two sides. You can mix and match these depending on how many people are playing and how you want to play. You can play a pretty quick one-on-one game by only using one game board. These are still pretty fun and help reduce your playtime from 3-5 hours to about an hour, for when you just don't have until 3am to play a game. Two connect the two small boards, this version adds "mobile teleporter" pieces. At the beginning of the game, players can each place one set of matched-number teleporters between any two territories. This can make each game different and change the dynamic of where everyone can attack and be attacked from.

If you flip the two small game boards over, you have a different map that is intended to be connected horizontally, for a very long game board which is supposed to be reminiscent of an actual Halo ringworld. This is quite fun as well, but requires a very big table or a lot of floor space, and preferably at least 4 players.

Then there are some other game dynamics, such as the territory cards. Traditionally, you keep these until you are ready to trade them in for units. In Halo Legendary Risk, you can still do this, or you can trade the cards instead for various bonus features depending on what it says on the card. There are also mission cards ranked by Halo-style difficulty (Easy, Heroic, Legendary). You can use these or not, again depending on how close you want to stick to traditional Risk rules.

The game pieces and dice (black and green) are pretty cool. UNSC humans have Marines (1 unit), Scorpion Tanks (3 units) and a Spartan as their hero. Covenant gets Grunts (1 unit), Wraith (3 units) and Elite/Arbiter as their hero. Flood has the small flood spore (1 unit), Flood Carrier (3 units) and for the hero, the giant flood brute monster thingy I only really recognize from some levels in the actual Halo Wars game.

Other than that, it's Risk. Roll dice, attack armies, capture territories. A fun, classic game, updated for all the Halo nerds out there.
summary: Another excellent variant of Risk for the Halo fan

Wow! A blast from the past! I remember building this  or attempting to build this  with my son. Now its with m grandchildren, who are just about to leave the age where things like KNEX are exciting.

 KNEX sets are interesting in strange ways. They are to as straight-forward as the old Gilbert Erector sets or Kenners Girders and Panels. Nor are they as elegant and suitable to endless manipulation as Legos.

 They are distinctive and challenging. The young person with mind geared toward spatial relationships and possessed of manual dexterity may love them. The impatient child may very well hate them.

 This set can build three models per the instructions. All will be a bit finicky to put together. All will difficult to keep together for any length of time.

 But for the patient and the careful, building them is a fun, if slightly demanding experience, and when you behold that gigantic almost three feet tall wheel turning, its Wow! I did that!

 Great fun.

Jerry
summary: First with my son  and now with my grandchildren.

reviewText: The instructions for putting together this robot are simple..the pictures are clear and accurate. Some parts were trickier than others to attach... not because of the directions, but because of their locations. I think it would be very helpful to have small, dainty fingers when putting this together because there were times when I found it rather difficult to get my medium sized female fingers into the tiny areas where these screws had to go, and not only that, but to hold the tiny washers in place at the same time. There are so many parts that it will take you hours and hours to put this together. It's recommended for age 10 and up but I cannot imagine a 10 year old being able to put this together by themselves. I put it together myself for my 8 year old, which was a shame because I would have liked for her to have been able to do it herself, or at least a lot of it herself as I think it would have been a rewarding experience for her to be able to see the end result of all her hard work. It's just too difficult though for a child to put together without help. I spent seven hours putting this together, only to get to the final part... assembling and attaching the feet, and realizing I had no long screws. I did purchase this as a "wearhouse deal, in very good condition". To me, that meant the box was damaged, not that it would be missing 16 or so screws. I'll be conscious of that next time I purchase an Amazon wearhouse deal. When I called Amazon they said they couldn't help me, so I called the company...Spin Master, located in Canada, and they were excellent. They immediately mailed out all the screws I need to finish this robot, at no cost to me. Unfortunately it will take at least a week to receive them in the US. I'm expecting to spend at least another two hours on just assembling and attaching the feet, although it may be less..that's just a guess judging by all the tiny screws and washers I still have left over that I'm guessing the instructions will tell me to use for the feet. It's an interesting toy, quite interactive and funny at times with his jokes and little remarks. He shakes hands, does hive fives, knows his name. That's about as far as we've got with him though..he doesn't always hear a command even when it's directed right towards the area you're supposed to speak into, and I do wish he was a little louder too...unless the room is very quiet, it's often difficult to hear what he's saying. We haven't been able to use the app with him...it just doesn't seem to be working, and it appears that if you want to use a phone with this, which you can attach to the front of him, you would need an iPhone. We cannot attach an Android phone, it's too big. Once I get the screws and can attach his feet and wheels, I think my daughter will enjoy this little guy. Just have patience, and put aside a day to put him together and you'll be fine.
summary: Long time to put together, but we like him

reviewText: Great toy. Great price. My nephew over there and couldn't wait to start playing with it right away. So many fun functions.

It takes about two rounds to learn how to play the game and during that time it can be very annoying/hard to understand but after that, this game gets better the more you play it. My friends and I absolutely love the fact that we can play with three players or with seven (though in my opinion 5-7 players is most optimal). This easily became our favorite board game in our friend group and we began to add expansions after about 30 games or so with the base game. The expansions add even more depth and variety so I recommend them some day if this game ever begins to get a little dull for you but the base game by itself is absolutely spectacular so don't rush it! Drafting is fun and randomly dealing out Wonders is fun. One of the best games I've ever played in my life.
summary: Spectacular game that easily scales from 2-7 players!!

I thought I would at least give it a shot and to my surprise he immediately took to the pacifier that came with the Bop Buddie. It was love at first sight!

I was really surprised he liked the pacifier but so happy I tried it before writing it off! He loves it! He just holds onto the little lamb and touches it's soft ears and fur while he is sucking on his pacifier.

In addition to the baby loving the lamb and having a soft cuddly toy for comfort with him at all times, there are several benefits for me! His old pacifier used to disappear on me ALL the time. I was constantly on the hunt for the pacifier and it could be hiding in plain view because it was hard to see. This one is much harder to miss!

The other thing I really like is that if it drops (when it drops) it doesn't bounce off and disappear like the other ones. Those things can bounce! He also seems to drop this one less; maybe because he's actually holding onto the lamb whereas the other pacifier would just be sitting in his mouth so if he opened his mouth at all, it would fall out.

The one thing I don't like so much is that it's white so it's harder to keep clean. It does wipe off with warm water and mild soap as directed but I wonder how long I'll be able to keep it clean. Yesterday Lambie went to the beach with us and took some abuse from the sand!

I'm surprisingly impressed with the Bop Buddie and all of the benefits that wouldn't have even occurred to me had I not tried it. And of course most importantly, Jax loves it too!

The Bop Buddie provides an attached cuddle toy for comfort to something they already use for comfort.

The fact that the bus is only three inches long turned out to be a bonus for us, since it allows him to bring it just about anywhere -- and he does: to the park, to church, to the grandparents' house, to his friends' houses, with him in the car, and everywhere in between.  Like other reviewers have noted, it's made in Thailand and not China (hooray!), and the wheels are on very tight.  We have had some of the paint wear off, but it's not very noticeable, and quite frankly, I'm surprised not more has worn off given how much the kid plays with it.  This Christmas, I will certainly make sure that Santa puts one of these in all our friends' kids' stockings.  It's a great toy!

reviewText: The added addition to my son's collection has allowed him and his nephew to build many more creations. This set is a great place to start.

I have in the past built several paper models that were extremely similar to these metal versions in layout and assembly, so my husband thought a couple of these would be a nice little project for me. Well, after my epic failure with this Tie Fighter, I'm not sure I have the motivation or skill required to attempt my X-Wing Starfighter. Before you try any of these metal model kits, read over the reviews and get all the tips and warnings from those who have tried and failed before you!

I only got about halfway finished, because in my attempts to bend a piece to the proper angle I snapped it apart. As someone else mentioned, you have maybe two bends before the pieces will break, so be certain of what you're doing. I accomplished inserting/folding the tiny tabs by using both tweezers and hobby pliers, but it was still difficult. And talk about sharp edges---they aren't kidding! I suppose it's a bonus of sorts that the pieces are sharp enough for you to slit your wrists and end your own suffering at any point in the build.

The ad copy on the package is laughable: "Simply pop out the pieces and connect using tabs and holes." Three stars because I'm sure these metal kits are even cooler than my paper versions, for those who can actually get them assembled that is.
summary: Ouch! (And some other words that can't be printed here.)

My son is 3, almost 4. Flarp! has held his attention longer than most of his toys, and in fact he liked it enough he wanted a second can for outside his playroom. It's cheap and entertaining, so why not?

What is flarp? It's a sort of oozy gel/putty. The scented flarp smells alright (my son likes it), and leaves your fingers smelling faintly of it, though the smell washes right off. You play with it as a single piece, using it to make noises.

How do you play with it? Take the putty out, put it back into its container with an air bubble below it. Poke your finger (or several fingers) in it to make air pressure, and the air 'flarps' out the sides as the flarp gets pushed down, sounding an awful lot like farts. I would NOT play with flarp outside its container.

Given how gooey it feels, it comes off the fingers surprisingly well, leaving just a little scent behind. Another reviewer complained about it ruining carpet. Very easy to believe! This is one of those toys you want to play with on a safe playspace, like a table with a plastic tablecloth.

As long as you take precautions, this is a toy that will appeal to toddlers, at least the ones who are entertained by "smellys."

(This rating is actually 4 and a half stars).
This is definitely one of the Best minifigures from the LEGO MOVIE minifigure series!
The printings on her torso (front and back) and the lower-body is pretty ok , but no printing on the side of the torso. And no printing on the side or on the back of the lower-body. Anyway , not something uncommon with LEGO. It looks awkward, so wish someday LEGO would start printing on the side of the torso also, and , for the female minifigure, printing on the side and back of the lower-body.
The hairpiece ,which includes a removable hat, is perhaps the best part of the minifigure, the one that adds beauty to it! The design of the hairpiece is pretty good (luckily not one of the common female-hairpieces). The hat, which can be added and removed from the hair, is pretty good. (And I love this design where you have the liberty of removing the hat from the hairpiece; previously, if I remember correctly, the hat used to come attached to the hair).
The face printing..is fantastic! Her face is very robot-like (she IS a robot) , with huge piercing orange-eyes and some pink on her cheeks. Very nice! And very scary too! My review philosophy:
As a longtime customer of Amazon, I depend on others' honest reviews. I do my best to provide that same courtesy to others.
I purchase lots of items through Amazon, some I get for free, some I get at a discounted rate, and some I pay full price. I will always disclose if I receive an item for free or a discounted rate. I do a lot of reviews so here is a break down on how I determine my star rating of a product:
5 stars  I love it! It is awesome and I highly recommend everyone to purchase this product!
4 stars  I like it, but there are some flaws. Don't we all have flaws? I would purchase again.
3 stars - It was okay, but I would probably not buy it again unless there are no other options.
2 stars  There may be worse products out there, but you can definitely find better choices.
1 star  I dislike the product, I wish I had not purchased it and recommend others to not purchase.

reviewText: Broke

There are those who buy Star Wars toys to collect, new in box, mint condition, never opened, sitting on the shelf. There are those who buy Star Wars toys to take them out and display, handle gently, and arrange it just so. There are those who will buy the Star Wars toys and manhandle them like they were meant to be played with. If you are in the last category, move along. This toy will not handle the rigors of childhood. Panels will snap off left and right, causing endless frustration. This star destroyer was not designed to do battle. Count me in the second group. I like to open my Star Wars toys. After all, what's the point of buying a toy if it just sits in a box? On the other hand, I don't really play with them so much as rearranging them on the shelf. This is the toy for me. What I love about it is the attention to detail. I placed the figures and ship under a digital microscope to take photos and was amazed that something the size of the tip of my finger could have so much detail. The ship itself did not require much assembly. Just place two pieces together. There was one sheet of stickers, but they are small stickers and it took me awhile to place them. I wish they would have put the stickers on for me, because I made some mistakes and can't get them on perfectly. There is one piece I think I need to superglue down, but I think it will be fine once I do that. The ship opens up to look sort of like a set on a movie. A cannon unfolds and shoots one laser. There's a plastic rod that hangs an X-wing above the cannon, so I presume we should imagine that laser is coming from the X-wing. Great for displays. When the ship is closed, it holds all the small pieces except for the TIE fighter. Speaking of small pieces, they are not metal like I expected. They are very pliable plastic. I love those pieces. When you see the detail, you will, too.
summary: Adults Only -- Not to be Played With

Great highly detailed versions of the original Ghostbusters cars. The Ecto-1 and 1A from GB 1 and 2. They are quite stunning. I was not expecting the level of paint details on the roof equipment of either. Also interesting is the cars themselves are different die cast tooling. They are not simply the same body with alternate plastic parts. Well done Mattel. Ecto-1A is particularly sharp with all the extra paint and tampo detailing. Not perfect, but quite good for the scale and price.

The only negatives I can give it; The Pearl White metalic paint is a little too overdone and obvious. They might have been better served with a simple gloss white. And the lightbars use metalic paint rather than transclear parts. Granted the paint does catch the light and give acceptable results for the lightbars.

Overall this is probably the single best product offering tied to the new Ghostbusters reboot movie. Really the only thing worth getting. (Yeah sorry, no kid anywhere ever asked for a Melissa McCarthy Action Figure.) Grab this set when you see it.
summary: Perfect little versions of Ecto-1 and 1A

reviewText: This is a really cool twist to the classic stacking rings.  The base level (the feet) has a post and you put the yellow, red, green/clear rings on in order and finish off putting on the head.  The rings do have orientation to them in that they aren't flat so there is a top and bottom and a front and back.  You can put them on "wrong" but even with a ring inverted and another on backwards they owl's head still goes on and it looks good.  All the pieces are different with rings, beads, wings or textures to keep them all interesting. The littlest players won't get the orientation of the parts and the older kids seem to like the additional challenge.  The wings are very chewable and it's easy to wipe off to clean.  The directions say 4m+ but it's good for younger kids just as something cute and friendly to look at during tummy time.  It's a great toy!
summary: A really cool twist to the classic stacking rings

reviewText:
My husband & I get so tickled to see our 6 year old grandson's excitement over the prospect of Grandpa taking a day off of work on July 18th to accompany us to the "Planes" sequel, called "Fire & Rescue"!  He's enjoyed the "Cars" and original "Planes" movies SO much, as well as the diecasts we've collected for him.  We understand Pinecone is a member of the "Smokejumpers" (along with leader Dynamite, Avalanche, Blackout and Drip), a ground crew that's transported via an ex-military plane called Cabbie and parachutes down to clear debris caused by wildfires.  Pinecone is an easygoing Southern gal who has a handy rake, and recalling how much our grandson loved a construction crew called "The Pack" during his Thomas the Train phase, I know this group of characters will become new favorites when Christmas rolls around!  One thing that should be noted is that Pinecone's rake doesn't actually move on this diecast model.

Pinecone is one of the good-sized Smokejumpers, measuring @ 3-1/4"L, 2"W, 2"H.  The 1:55 scale Mattel models have become our preference based on our experience over the past few years.  They have more of a sturdy plastic feel, and now that we have a 2 year old grandson as well who is a lot rougher on toys than our older one was, durability is our primary consideration (especially since we have another grandson making his debut around Labor Day)... with three boys to make it through (and hopefully GREAT grandchildren someday!), the toys we buy have to be tough.  The Disney Store models we've purchased were larger (1:43 scale) and had a heavier metal concentration, but LOOK OUT if they rolled off of the coffee table - parts were breaking off like crazy.  The Mattel collections have held their own.  Pinecone is included in the Welcome to Piston Peak 7 pack (the ONLY multipack with ALL FIVE Smokejumpers!) and a 3 pack with model # CLJ30.  I'm putting some general info for anyone considering collecting more than one or two of these models in the comments section below, in case you're interested.
summary: Pinecone - member of Piston Peak's "Smokejumpers" team!

reviewText:
I bought Spyrium at a discount so I wouldn't feel too bad if I never played it twice.  Turns out to be exactly what most people say it is: a good medium-weight worker-placement/resource-management game with a superficial steampunk theme.  The wooden meeples look just like those from Carcassonne, and the artwork is decent if uninspiring.  Cards are good quality, and the green spyrium crystals are fun.  All of that aside, the economy of decisions is the real draw for this type of game, and Spyrium is a good example of the genre.

It's a board game without a board, other than a small scoring track.  This plus the 3 x 3 "market" of buildings, characters, and technique cards gives Spyrium a relatively small footprint.  Two people can sit side-by-side and play this on a coffee table, since everything is visible to all other players.  With 5 players it was a different experience.  Spyrium has a mechanic that allows you to earn money when you choose to remove workers from the board, so with 12 to15 meeples crowding the market, you can accumulate a lot of money more efficiently than with 2 players.  The turns are relatively short, since you only have a few options.  Expect a complete game to last about 25 minutes per player.

As a personal preference, I like games with scoring tracks.  Like most worker-placement games, Spyrium gives players the chance for a big point grab at the end, so a player could jump ahead by 10 points on the track during the game, and still find themselves beaten by someone who chose a strategy for the "long game".  My game group plays a lot of Carcassonne, Puerto Rico, and Lords of Waterdeep.  Spyrium is a little different from any of these and went over really well.  I expect it will get several more plays.
summary: Meeples and buildings and money and green crystal things.  It's fun.

So I found them here after searching all over. I thought just my one year old would play with them, however, my daughter now almost 3 pretty much took them over! She hasn't mastered opening them but comes to me asking me to "open her eggs" She and her brother are occupied for hours with these. She has learned the shapes and where they fit, she learned that they "hatch" without me telling her. She matches the correct shell to the correct egg and knows the colors of the eggs. My one year old carries them around while crawling or coasting and likes to put them in his mouth (they don't fit- no choking hazard) and both enjoy squeaki squeaking them. I would say that this is one of their favorite toys... and mine too because 1. Its educational 2. Teaches motor skills 3. It's not electronic 4. It is compact and packs away neatly and is portable too. I will be buying this as a gift for other kids.

reviewText:
I like this figure a lot, but due to some quality control issues Im a bit miffed, especially for the price you pay. I really liked the Revoltech Stormtrooper and I like this Boba Fett for much of the same reasons, fantastic sculpt and articulation and accessories. But the qc issues with both figures makes me think that I will be passing on any future releases in this line.

So the sculpt, amazing. And the sculpt is enhanced by the stellar paint job, no bleeding or smudges on these paint applications. You get his Blas Tech EE-3 Blaster rifle, that although it doesnt have dry brushing on the barrel like the Hasbro Black Series Fett, I think this has a better all-around paint job. This rifle has a good feature too, the stock can be pulled up so you can slide the handle into the figures hand without having to force it in and break something. You also get Fetts Sacros K-11 disintegrator pistol that can be holstered in a nice soft rubbery holster unlike the hard plastic on the Revoltech Stormtrooper. Boba Fett comes packaged with fisted hands and included are two relaxed palms for holding the barrel of his rifle, and two trigger fingered hands. Now here is another issue I have, instead of getting a right and left trigger hand, I got two right triggered hands, not cool. The pictures on the back of the box show right and left trigger hands, and why would you want two of the same hand? Obviously I was supposed to get a right and a left, I wonder what other dude got two left trigger hands? Hit me up, maybe we can trade so we actually have the correct set of hands!

Here are some other issues I have with the figure, the right leg is longer than the left. It has nothing to do with the Revoltech joints, I pulled this figure apart (which is actually easy to do and kinda cool that you can unplug all of the limbs and move around the joints if you want to line them up better/differently) and the right leg is a few millimeters longer than the left, making it impossible to stand this figure without having to bend the right leg or pose it. So I cant get him to stand just straight legged, annoying. The tips on the end of his boots are pointy for stabby kicking action, and also fragile breaking action. Im not sure if this was broken before I took him out of the box or not, but since the package is hassle free, Im not sure how or when I broke off one of the boot tips or if it was packaged broken, lame. Also, his cape shouldn't be green, this is the Empire Strikes Back version of Fett and so it should be beige with a brown stripe. If this were the Jedi version with red gauntlets, then it should have the green cape. And I think I would have preferred a soft goods cape and not soft plastic like this. I know people don't like the look of the joints but for me that isn't an issue. Fragility and breaking parts is my biggest issue with figures and this figure line in general.

 I know it sounds like Im bashing this figure but other than some valid issues, I really like this figure. I think in terms of design and paint, this kills the Black Series version, especially in articulation. I like that his antenna on his helmet articulated, I like the accessories and aesthetic of the figure, its just the qc issues mainly that kept this from getting a 5 star rating. If the figure was only $20-$30 it would get a 5 star rating. If I got the correct set of hands Id be able to forgive the tiny broken foot tip and slightly longer leg. Unless you're a die hard Boba Fett fan, you may want to pass on this due to the price and chances that youll have issues with yours as well. Still, this figure comes APPROVED.

Picked up Deadend today and found it a fairly good toy. It is, admittedly, a repaint of Wheeljack with a new head sculpt, but the coloring is strikingly different. He has an intricate transformation that wasn't particularly difficult, I actually enjoyed it, but a young child might get a little frustrated. The range of motion and articulation is good, if not amazing and the gaudy color scheme really helps him stand out from the original Wheeljack mold (not to mention the new head sculpt is completely different). He seems a little more durable than some of the other Prime toys, but I can't accurately attest to it since I don't really do much more than fiddling around with mine (mostly they sit on a shelf), but the plastic gave me the impression it wasn't quite as flimsy as some. Overall I quite like him and if you don't mind recolorings (a staple practice for new Transformer toys) I highly suggest picking one up if you can find it.

We play with Megabloks and Duplo at our house and are always happy to add a fun new set. This set is one that is geared at the much younger toddler. The bloks are large and work well with other First Builder sets but are too big for the average Megablok or Duplo. The food truck is larger than I had originally expected but in line with other First Builder sets. This does not take the place of a toy kitchen as it is too small for that purpose. When my granddaughter (who is under one year old) wants to play with the blocks, we place it on the ground. She can crawl to it, sit by it, and even use it as a support to stand up next to. She is only interested in chewing on the blocks. To make it more versatile, we have placed it on a small folding table so my three year old grandson can play with it standing up. He is more interested in cooking and loves all the cooking related items in the set. He helps his Mommy and Daddy cook at home and wants to be able to cook for Nana and Papa when he comes to visit. In the end, I found it a good toy. My only issue had to do with the size and purpose. The size is appropriate for a younger child where the purpose is better for an older one but it is too small on its own for the older child. Setting it on the table solved that issue for us.

WowWee's "Little Mermaid" from their "Once Upon a Zombie" line is a very beautiful doll!

It's really nice to see new interpretations of the titular character from Hans Christian Andersen's fairytale "The Little Mermaid"(1837). Rarely do we see original takes on classic fairytale characters in doll form other than Disney's adaptations in the market today.

Little Mermaid from Once Upon a Zombie is a really beautiful take on Andersen's character with a fun twist; she's been zombified! She has a beautiful face with rooted eyelashes, blue eyeshadow, green inset eyes, pale blue lips and delicate stitching running down her cheeks. Her hair, although not the best of quality, is still soft out of the box and is parted and styled quite nicely. The doll's look really works well in context with the tragic fairytale of "The Little Mermaid".

Little Mermaid's body and articulation are also top quality with 11 points of articulation. All parts of her body are sturdy and are nicely articulated. Aesthetically, her body looks really good. She has this pale greyish skin and a few delicate stitching details. I'm glad they didn't go overboard with the stitching details which would have come off gaudy had they done so. Another really great feature of her body is that she has fuller features like her torso and arms. She's a zombie but has a much more healthy looking body than many other dolls in the market. Ironic.

Costume-wise is where Little Mermaid slightly disappoints but at the same time impresses. Little Mermaid has a pretty starfish accessory for her hair which is a really nice touch. Her top is the best feature of her costume. She has a molded seashell top that looks fantastic, a mermaid seashell top done right. So often fabric is used for seashell tops on mermaid dolls and they don't look nearly as good as this molded top. Now, where Little Mermaid slightly disappoints also happens to be the most important part of her costume, her fishtail. The polka dot fabric just doesn't look very good and it's only half a fishtail with her legs being exposed...why? It doesn't make much sense and it doesn't look good. It would have been really nice if she had a proper mermaid fishtail with her fins being jagged as if ripped like a real fish. I mean in the context of the fairytale I get it. It seems as if she was in the middle of her human transformation but it would have been much nicer if she had a proper fishtail.

Overall, a wonderful doll with the only disappointment being her mermaid fishtail. Little Mermaid has a gorgeous face, lovely hair, a great body,one of the best doll mermaid tops, and a really nice starfish accessory. I love her color scheme, the blue makeup and blonde hair work very well for her. She's a very original and pretty take on Andersen's character. Although Fairy Tale High's Little Mermaid is a really nice doll, I can't help but wish her design was more original like Once Upon a Zombie's Little Mermaid. I look forward to the web-series and more dolls from this line! It'd be really cool if non-zombie versions were also released, based from the web-series trailer the fairytale princesses also have beautiful non-zombie character designs.

reviewText: Great, as expected!

Beast Hunters Bulkhead is one cool Autobot! I will admit this is the one deluxe beast hunters transformer I was most skeptical about,but I took a chance on it and am glad I did because this is one really good version of Bulkhead overall. The paint job with the green and gold really look cool with the reptilian scale armor. I like the the visor look on the head piece as well. Bulkhead also comes with one sweet weapon in a spinning Dragon Grinder that attaches to either the forearm or back in robot mode and securely on the roof or doors in armored truck mode. The spinning action on the weapon is very cool for a more realistic effect and is very easy to operate. The poseability is outstanding with great stability for creating cool battle scenes or displaying where you please. The durability is excellent as well with secure ball joint construction and a solid build in either mode. All parts fit together securely during the transformation process for a quality constructed transformer all around. The transformation level is intermediate meaning if you have plenty of experience with transformers there is mid-level difficulty. If you are a parent buying for a child of 5-6 you might need to assist some in the transformation process. First off the side pieces on the hood will slide in as the roof piece with the doors on the back rotates forward over the head. Next the arms rotate around so the fist are facing outwards. Now the forearms rotate in as do the fists. The arms will have the look like Bulkhead is flexing his muscles. The arms will rotate down and then in. The wheels will then slightly rotate out as the bottom section rotates forward. The front piece with the autobot symbol rotates down as the front fender and grill connect together. The autobot symbol piece rotates back up as the hood piece with the roof and doors will rotate forward to connect together. Next is the only real tricky part. You have to get the arms just right for everything to connect together. Basically the arms will be in a v-shape with the fist facing down with the knuckles on the outside. The doors will rotate down as the feet pieces will rotate in. The legs now connect together then will rotate up to form the back section of the armored truck. The doors now connect into place and Bulkhead is ready to roll out! If you are a fan of the Autobot bruiser Bulkhead this is a worthwhile transformer to add to your world of transformers. Bottom line Transformers Beast Hunters Bulkhead is a high quality,well-made,10 out of 10 transformer all fans will enjoy. I highly recommend Transformers Beast Hunters Bulkhead to all transformers fans and collectors out there. Bulkhead Rocks and Transformers Rule!!!

reviewText:
I currently own a Walkera CB100 fixed pitch micro heli so this is my second 4ch fixed pitch micro heli. This little heli flies great and is very responsive. It's capable of fast forward flight as well as very stable hovers when trimmed correctly and flown indoors. The frame is very light and very durable. The landing struts are very flexible so it's highly unlikely to break. The main rotor blades are very durable too. The tail boom is a carbon square rod which keeps the tail rotor at a near perfect vertical position. Parts are readily available and cheap too. Compared to my Walkera it's much more responsive given that all up weight is less due to the smaller battery and all plastic head/swash plate/flybar. It's also much more durable as parts just flex instead of getting bent or broken. The radio is pretty nice for the price. It's 2.4GHz and it has a backlit LCD with digital trims and get this..a Dual Rate button! Switching the D/R on/off allows the servos' throw to be decreased/increased respectively. Also this transmitter seems to be the same one used on the Align T-Rex 100 combo and that radio alone sells for around $60!

With that said it wasn't perfect out of the box as mine had a tendency to lean to the back/right. I had to adjust the right roll (aileron) trim to the max and the forward pitch (elevator) trim halfway to get it to hover in one spot. Being a somewhat experienced R/C hobbyist I disconnected the ball links to make adjustments to the length of the rods so that when the trims were at dead center the heli would hover without the need for significant trim adjustments. I've flown this heli outdoors on slightly breezy days and it flies fine and I'm not even that great of a pilot. On a related note the gyro holds the heli solidly which helps a lot. I would've given this package 5 stars if the heli didn't have to be trimmed to the max in order to hover.

Update: After about 10 flights I noticed that the antenna on the heli came loose as the solder joint was not soldered correctly. Since I had a soldering iron and some solder handy I fixed it and it's flying great again however it's good advice to check your solder joints on your heli after you buy these as the quality control can be hit or miss. I've already ordered a second one of a different color and 5 larger capacity 150mah LiPo battery packs. That should get me about 1 hr of flying time (8 min per battery + 7 min each stock battery) with brief breaks for battery changes. The stock battery gives 7 minutes of indoor hovering..not bad at all.

Important tip: If your heli suddenly starts to spin wildly after many normal flights, check the tail motor/rotor for hairs/lint stuck on the motor shaft...ask me how I know. Not only will your heli not be able to hover but the tail motor will get very hot and may burn out if there are hairs/lint stuck around the shaft. Luckily I noticed it early enough on my heli as the motor did get hot!
summary: Fast, responsive, stable, low cost and durable (Updated Review with maintenance tip at the end)

If your child loves machines, designing and building things, or toys that do something, then ZOOB Car Designer may be ideal for them.  This building toy fosters imagination and creativity; it allows a child to realize their vision in a three-dimensional form.

ZOOB Car Designer features 88 hard plastic pieces.  Twelve wheels have studded rubber tires.  An additional 76 red or blue pieces can be used to construct the body of the vehicle.  Although there is an included instruction book detailing how to build 13 vehicles, a child can conceptualize and build a vehicle of their own design.  All pieces are finished cleanly  there are no visible seams or rough edges.

This is a toy for any child who loves to build things or create three-dimensional objects.  ZOOB Car Designer is a toy that parents or grandparents can have fun sharing with their child.  My grandson  and his father  loved ZOOB Car Designer so much they built things for hours without stopping.  Definitely a five-star toy!

reviewText:
This spider is a fun little toy for the whole family.... so far, it is most popular with our cat who loves to chase it around the house and play with it.  I'm not sure who is winning but I think the spider isn't going to last long at the rate our cat is throwing it around.  Unboxing was fairly  simple and took me about 30 seconds.  There were two toggles I had to unscrew (by hand, not screwdriver thankfully) and they quickly released it from the packaging.  It comes with the battery installed so play begins as soon as you pull the plastic battery strip out of the battery compartment.

There are  two sensors on top that you touch (have to touch both at same time) to change between the 3 different modes:

1.  Attack mode (RED EYES):  Aim the spider at your destination (preferably little sister or sleeping cat) and put on the floor.  The spider goes in a straight line until he makes contact with said object.  Little sister smashes spider and you have to buy a new one.  Planned obsolescence.

2.  Creek mode (BLUE EYES):  Spider slowly rolls around to explore immediate surroundings.  Good for when you put him in the included cage.

3.  Explore mode (GREEN EYES): Random exploration of a larger area.

This toy is not a $100 Roomba.  There are no edge sensors so yes it will fall down stairs, but mine fell down and no harm done.  Also there is no sensor to tell when it has hit a wall, so it just keeps pushing against the wall until the random program sends it in a different direction.  On the latter point it would be nice if it sensed the wheels were locked up and immediately switched into another mode, and would make play more fun because the spider could back up if you touch it and block it's way.  That would add more realism to the play.

On the bottom there is an "on off" switch, two wheels, the battery compartment, and of course the MADE IN CHINA stamp.

As for the battery, one star off.  It would be great if this were rechargeable or used more commonly available batteries.  It requires THREE "button cell AG13 LR44 battery and I'm guessing that you, like me, have never heard of that type and don't have them around the house.  If this is a gift you might want to order some extras.

Overall a fun toy, one star off for the strange battery and inability to backup immediately when it hits a wall, but other than that this will provide your kids or your pets with a lot of fun play.
summary: Whole family loves it including the cat.  Note special batteries are included but you may need to stock up

reviewText:
Listing was for 75.  This was a simple re-order from December, except that it was the same price for 100 - decembers order was a good deal with great quality.  I should have noticed the count difference, my fault I did not.

That said, I got less than 50.  And of those, less than 1 in 2 were usable (see pics).  The quality was so bad, I had no choice but to take the time to return.

As all moms of boys know, if these don't come in great quality (tip glued securely, bullet in tact, straight, with no debts, cuts, dings, etc) they jam inside the guns and you generally have to have a degree in Mecanical Engineering to find the stuck bullet and find a way to get it out of the gun, without breaking the gun (FYI I like the small bent hanger approach for those interested), while said son waits as patiently as possible and offers as much well intended help and ideas as possible, which all mom's love and appreciate - but when less than 1 of every bullets arrives "new" yet unusable, said son runs out of patience and so does said mom.

As I had stated, I've ordered several times before this and was thrilled. But as I indicated with the note in my return (afraid I would not get a return for sending back less than 75, since I got less than 75) -- mom just doesn't have time for the quality control for this company.

I'm off to find a new, more reliable, less costly, better quality supplier of Nerf style bullets and would recommend anyone else save your time and hard earned $$'s and do the same.
summary: Got less than 50 and those were really bad quality. .  Very disappointed

My five year old son got this toy as a gift, at first he was a bit leery to play with it and I can certainly understand why. The face is scary and the toy is heavy, however he soon go over his trepidation and started playing and having fun with The Hulk.

I think that this is possibly the best action figure he has, there are 14 points on this toy and it is solid and heavy. The feet on The Hulk are Huge, but the center of gravity is off so making him stand without the enclosed platform takes a short amount of practice.

The most impressive aspect of this action figure, as mentioned, is the fantastic sculpted detail. The anger on The Hulk's face is unmatched with any other like toy I have seen, even his eyeballs are angry and the whole face is filled with rage. The sculpted muscles, exaggerated as they may, look great in the playroom or on display. However, I must admit that my favorite part of the action figure is the pants, not because I'm a fashionista, not at all, but the level of the attention to detail is phenomenal and, to me, represents the quality of the piece.

Everyone who loves The Hulk concentrate on the important features, the angry face, the grinning teeth, the blazing eyes and, of course the embellished muscles - but many overlook the finer details. To me, the fact that no small detail was overlooked, not even the rips and tears and the least important part of the piece, says a lot.
summary: An intricate and detailed representation of The Incredible Hulk

We were lucky enough to be given this Easy Bake Oven as a gift for my 6 year old daughter. There are just a few notes that I want to share with others who may be considering this item. These are not necessarily complaints, I'm not whining....I'm just sharing information to hopefully save the next consumer some time.  :)

1. The knobs and "timer" on the front aren't real. Not a big deal, but it just may not be clear to someone just looking at the pictures on the box.
2. You push the cake pan in one side, and then out the other the other side when it is done....everything only goes one way.
3. Since the exit door only opens one way, you unfortunately can't push the pan back into the oven if you find that your cake is not done after the recommended time. You also can't put it back into the original entrance because the entrance slot is smaller than the exit slot, so ANY rise of the cake makes it too big to fit back in.
3. You can't see into the oven to see if it is done or not. I wish we could see when the middle of our cake is runny and not nearly done. Sometimes we have to pop our cakes into our toast over to finish them off.
4. I was using a recipe that I found online for Easy Bake cakes using ingredients you have at home. This is definitely the way to go, but it takes some experimentation to figure out how much to use. Of our first 5 cakes all of them either overflowed or got the tops scraped off as we pushed them out of the oven. (The recipe I used says to combine 1/3 cup of the dry mix with 4 tsp water for one little cake; however this proved to be too much...I ended up finally using about 1/4 cup dry + 3 tsp water instead to avoid crazy overflow messes inside the Easy Bake oven and to avoid a too tall cake for the allotted exit space.)
5. I would recommend filling the little pan LESS than half full, and remember to butter and flour the pan so the cake won't stick.
6. As far as cooking time, 12 minutes is what is recommended in the instruction book, but I needed 17 minutes to cook the most successful cake using the recipe I mentioned above.
7. My daughter especially likes the little warming trays in the side of the Easy Bake oven for melting chocolate chips (for dipping strawberries, etc.)
8. All in all, my daughter really likes the Easy Bake Oven and she gets a lot of help from me while we are figuring out the tricks to make this toy successful. It probably would be a mistake to expect a young child to be able to use it alone.

A few more discoveries:
9. It is not easy clean out the cooked-on overflowed batter from the inside of the Easy Bake Oven.
10. One helpful tip: if we cook the cake for about 12 minutes then unplug the oven, but leave the cake inside the cooking area of the oven (for about 5-6 more minutes) while the oven is cooling down, it lets the cake settle a little so it is less likely to get the top scraped off of it when we push it out.
summary: Works ok, but some experimentation needed

My daughter, age 6, and I really enjoy these blocks. I received this set free from Tryazon and Guidecraft in exchange for hosting a party and offering an honest review. All opinions and experiences are honest and my own. We had a party and children ages 3-11 used the IO Blocks to build. We used the included Build Cards - which are sturdy, colorful, and two-sided. We also built using our imaginations. This was the kids' favorite part! Some of the provided projects were simply too complicated for this age group. As a parent/homeschool mom, this is actually an awesome feature - these blocks will be great for hands-on thinking and learning until at least age 15. I can see my daughter building structures and using them for STEM projects for many years. They are sturdy, durable and the color is great. They connect well, but provide the opportunity for movement [great if you decide to use them for stop-motion animation projects!]. They could easily be mixed and mingled with other textiles [like playdough] for even more imaginative play and projects.

The only current drawback to these building blocks are that they come with a free app that just isn't quite up to par yet. The augmented reality app allows the builder to look up about 20 different build projects and see how they're put together. It is great to be able to see how the pieces of more complicated projects come together, especially if you find yourself stuck. However, right now, not every Build Card is included in the app and that left some of the children upset and frustrated. I think there is a lot of room for the app to grow, but the app is an add-on that is not vital to the enjoyment of these blocks!

There are an endless variety of ways to use these blocks for teaching and learning. They are recommended for ages 4 and up and I would agree. I think they're a great investment for any classroom. The children I partied with would agree. They said they would choose these blocks over any others if given the choice! They loved the colors, shapes, and puzzleyness of the blocks.
summary: Endless building and learning options! Great for all ages fun!

Prime Climb is a hit with pretty much the whole family! Preschooler is too young to do much more than roll the dice on someone's team, but 2nd grader and adults alike enjoy this. It's really a strategy game that employs a lot of math; I think it resembles a grown-up version of Chutes & Ladders with strategy. Addition, multiplication, subtraction and occasionally division inform what your possible moves are. So it certainly reinforces those math skills during game play. If a player is old enough for strategy but still needs a little help on the math, you as an adult can decide what level of assistance to give. The included 10x10 multiplication table is handy and a good tool for learning and game play, but it certainly doesn't include all possible multiplication problems you might encounter in the game. The color coding on the board is visually attractive and also helps double-check your multiplication.

The good mix of strategy and chance combine for engaging play. The practice on math skills is a wonderful bonus for us!
summary: a lot of fun for adults and older kids

reviewText: Perfect white elephant gift. Takes you back

My Son has several Nerf N Strike guns that range from the Automatic Stampede to the manual single shot Maverick.  I thought this Rayven would be a perfect complement but it turned out to be a very weak and dull shooter.  The gun takes 7 AA batteries in total divided between the clip and the gun itself.  The clip takes batteries to power a UV light that makes the special darts glow in the dark. This glow in the dark feature works well and has an on/off switch to save battery life when you are firing in the day.  The gun itself seems underpowered when compared to others such as the Stampede.  The mechanism requires you to hold down a button to power a motor before you can pull the trigger and actually fire a dart.  If the motor button isn't held down long enough then the darts are not fired with enough force to really be fun.  To make matters worse as the batteries deplete the gun fires with even less force making it useless in a Nerf gun battle.  Overall it is a good looking gun but the 2 button firing system and the relatively weak shots make it less fun than other Nerf Guns.

*** Positive Points: ***

- Interchangeable clips with other Nerf guns

- Glow in the dark darts work well and are priceless in nighttime battles

- Lightweight and easy to hold for younger children

*** Negative Points: ***

- Relatively weak shooting strength (when compared to other Nerf guns)

- Unnecessarily fussy having to hold down the motor button before pulling the trigger

- Requires 7 AA batteries total (3 for the clip to charge the glow in the dark darts and 4 for the gun)
summary: 3.5 Stars - Good Looking but Less Effective Than Other Nerf Guns
