I've been getting back into model making recently. I built Bandai's excellent 6'' R2-D2 and C-3PO, but I hadn't gotten any ships from The Force Awakens yet. Unfortunately, Bandai's ship models are difficult to get in the U.S. due to a licensing dispute with Disney, so I decided to try Revell's out offerings. Poe Damerons X-Wing isn't my favorite ship, but it seems like itll be one of the main ships in the new movie, so I decided to try it out.

First of all, this is only a model in a very loose sense. The pieces aren't attached to a rack so there's no cutting required. All the pieces snap together very easily. In fact, the entire construction took less than 10 minutes. So I wouldn't really recommend this for anybody looking for an involved build. In terms of difficulty, it's probably suited more to younger kids.

That said, the final product is a really nice version of Poe Damerons X-Wing. The ship is over 8 inches long. Its not as large as Hasbros X-Wing, but this model uses nice, hard plastic (these laser cannons won't bend) The ship itself is very detailed. The wings expand so the ship can go into attack formation and the cockpit opens. The interior is quite detailed, but sadly theres no figure. Best of all - and this was a surprise to me - the ship comes with pretty good sound effects!

The model comes partially prepainted, at least the major features like the orange stripes and the cockpit windows. It doesnt have any weathering or scoring, but I decided this ship looked better clean (I added a tiny bit of weathering inside the engine intakes).

The ship unfortunately isn't entirely accurate to the film because the tips of the laser cannons are sideways. Although Im disappointed, I cant say it takes away too much for me. I wouldnt even have noticed if another reviewer hadnt pointed it out. Truth be told, I actually prefer the laser cannons sideways. I realize this is reason enough for some people not to get the model, so hopefully Revell fixes this in the near future.

Another (tiny) complaint is that the model doesn't include a stand. It does have landing gear, which works well enough, but a stand would still have been nice to so we could display the ship in mid-flight.

If you're looking for a movie-accurate model/toy of Poe Damerons X-Wing, this is a good choice. It's certainly great value for your money. I remember getting the Action Fleet version of Luke Skywalkers X-Wing during the 1990s. It cost about $10-15, wasn't as accurate, and didn't have sounds. So $20 for this kit is a bargain.
summary: build your own Star Wars toy

We've purchased Mashoonga's in the past and they have been excellent. The product is very sturdy and my two boys love them. They smack each other to their hearts content without hurting each other. The last pair of swords we had lasted almost 5 years before the wear and tear forced me to replace them. I did it in a heartbeat though because of the quality. These things are so much fun and gives kids a chance to act out their favorite sword-fighting scenes without leaving a mark. I've used Star Wars licensed Lightsabers and Nerf Foam Swords, these are a lot better. The Star Wars swords are nice because of the lights and sounds and aesthetic but it's hard to actually play and not hurt anyone. The Nerf swords will lose their foam in a couple of bouts. It will look like they are all chewed up after. These Mashoonga swords are made of thick foam (similar to pool noodles), they come covered in a removable and washable sleeve. It's very convenient and fun. Highly recommended!
summary: Kids want to beat each other? You don't want them to actually hurt each other? Here's the answer.

Yellow dice are something everyone needs in their collection in my opinion.  These remind me of the first or second set of dice I got when I bought those old boxed sets back in the 80's (the red basic and the blue advanced ones).  Unlike those dice of old I didn't have to fill in the numbers with the included black crayon and these are made of a much better plastic that will survive the hundreds or thousands of rolls they are likely to receive.  I also like to buy dice of bright colors because everyone else has dark shades of one or another and since I DM a lot I like to share the crit or fail with my group in all its glory.

I purchased this as gift for my nephew.  He likes Legos so I thought this would be a fun, comparable alternative.  I put it together with him.  He is 7 and I assumed he could do it easily on his own but he did need a good bit of help.  To be honest I was confused myself.  We made the large plane that uses all the pieces on the cover of box.  I think all the pieces being clear adds a dimension of difficulty.  Overall,  he loved it and it looks great lite up.  It was cool to change the lighting to pulse.  The wing did fall off a couple of times during flight.  So, I will agree that the bricks may not stay together quite as well as Legos.  However,  it could just be the design and not the actual bricks.  I did have to detach two bricks I had placed together that were wrong and I almost couldn't get them apart...so, I guess that's an argument for them connecting just as well as Legos.  I think this was a good buy and good price.  Any Lego lover would probably love to incorporate these into their collection.

This is a terrific toy!  We got it for our 1-year-old, and we were very happy to find a cool doll that wasn't pink and that was rated safe for a 12-month-old to give to our little boy.  I will definitely be using this as a gift for birthday parties and the like for other boys in the 1-2.5 age range.

In terms of a choking hazard, the toy manufacturer rates this for 12-months or older.  I think that is just something that Amazon puts up to satisfy our liability-crazed social standards.  There is NOTHING I can see on this that looks to be a choking hazard, save for a snap or a 1" button on the pants (also a snap on the hat), but these are sewn on very well, and I am not sure a 1" button could cause choking on a 1-year plus child (though I'm sure there's some case in which it somehow did, hence the liability warning).  Ironically, by age 3, this toy would not be interesting/useful for most kids, who would have-- by then-- learned to dress themselves!

Finally, in terms of the lace being sewed on, this is just like the hat.  With a pair of scissors, both the shoe lace and that hat are removed (as is intended) so that the child can play with the full set of clothes.  These are likely sewn on only to ensure the pieces stay intact amid curious explorers at the toy store.
summary: Great way for boys (or girls) to learn to care for others via a doll toy

The Legacy Thunder Megazord is, to date, the most expensive item in the Legacy product line, and after spending some time with it I understand why.  It is both excellent and sub-par.

The Thunder Megazord is unique in the line of Power Rangers and Super Sentai because of it's core design.  Other entries in the series work with a very familiar practice; five-to-six components, one or two which make up the central frame while the other four snap on to become arms and legs regardless.  Bandai has further adapted this into a universal system called the "Zord Builder" series, effectively making components from other configurations compatible.  For instance, components of the Samurai Megazord in the Zord Builder series can be combined with the Legacy Tigerzord.  These two things, the Thunder Megazord's unique design, and the Zord Builder series, are why the product figuratively and literally falls apart.

The core component of the Thunder Megazord configuration is the Red Dragon.  It converts to a humanoid form, with arms and legs.  It is fairly articulate.  The design of the Thunder Megazord deviates from the Zord Builder series because the remaining four components do not snap on to the torso, rather the central piece wears them like armor.  The Red Dragon's legs are inserted into the Pegasus and Griffen.  The Lion is worn on the arm like sleeves or gloves, whereas the Firebird wraps around the midsection.  This is a fantastic design that makes it stand out among others in the product line.

However, the Legacy Thunder Megazord is also part of the Zord Builder line, which means certain backward-forward compatibility has to be forced.  The Legacy Tigerzord, which the Thunder Megazord should naturally be compatible with (as they are part of the same family / show) connects rather haphazardly.  The Tigerzord relies on the Zord Builder principle.  In order to accomplish this, rather than easily snap-in the other components for the arms and legs, pieces must be removed; pieces which some may not be entirely comfortable removing.

In order to properly combine this with the Legacy Tigerzord, first one must remove the toes/rear-legs of the Tigerzord.  These snap-in but they can be stubborn and working too stiffly may or may not cause damage to the small plastic molding which would otherwise hold them into place.  The Griffen and Pegasus each have a long, silver plate which needs to be removed so the pieces can align properly.  This came off easily on one of the pieces but required some work on the other.  This is not the entire assembly, mind you, this is simply the lower body.  In order to connect two pieces to the lower body four pieces have to be removed.  And set aside.  And not lost.  Ever.

The standalone Legacy Thunder Megazord looks fantastic, and after working with it I can understand why it was so expensive as it had to look great but also fit a square peg into a round hole.  It is only when expansion or customization is taken into account that it becomes problematic.

It is a must for collectors, but might be frustrating.

reviewText:
20+ years ago, we played Trivial Pursuit over and over and over again. Everybody was able to play and everybody was able to answer some questions because they were mostly based on general knowledge and trivia.

Not so anymore!  If a player is not extremely well-read and informed, they will be very bored because the questions are VERY difficult for the average person. If you don't play the "Easy" mode, you will be "playing" all night waiting for a question to answer.  The first time I played, we "got through it" and the second time, with a larger group, we gave up.  Nobody wants to "play" something and not be able to "play."

The set-up, design and concept of the game is nearly identical in the electronic version.  However, the digital "cards" -- because that's all that changed, is the cards are now in a hand-held digital contraption -- do not include the familiar categories and the navigation is cumbersome.  It is a three-step process to skip an insanely difficult question.  The categories are repeated.  The screen will show you, for example, Sports and Leisure I for yellow and Sports and Leisure II for green.  With nothing being different about how to play using the digital contraption, I say it's a waste of technology.  It would be better if, say, you land on blue and you choose blue (let's say its History) on the screen, then the screen would give the player a choice of questions in categories of Children's questions; Teen questions; World History, U.S. History, etc.

Bottom line.  Questions are too difficult for average people.  The digital contraption adds NOTHING to the game.  Definitely not nearly as enjoyable as it was many years ago.  It's not a family game, unless you are a family made up of only genius-level knowledge and trivia seekers.  Even then, don't expect many non-savant people under the age of 21 to be able to answer even one question.

I dont' even know if I want to keep the game I bought for me -- much less the second game I bought as a potential gift.

Scale model trains generally aren't hands-on toys, especially for smaller children.  They're fragile and they can easily fail to work and break irrepairably.  They can also be very costly in purchase price and in the investment of time and materials put into building a layout.  I won't extol all the virtues of model railroading but obviously it includes art in the scenery, science in the electrics and electronics, social science and even economics in modeling society and industry.  So they are much more than a toy and can become a life-long hobby or avocation for an interested person.  One way to get started is to research and buy the good stuff, not wasting your time and money on junk like this LL set.  But if you over estimate your child's readiness to work with a model versus a toy, your mistake can be costly.  You may also not appreciate what modeling takes in terms of how much work it is, how much space it takes, how much is involved in terms of skills and learning.

This train set has got to be the rock-bottom cheapest HO set out there.  If not, it's real close.  The weaknesses abound.  I won't elaborate on them all.  The train is not accurate to the prototype (the real thing#.  It's made with poorly detailed plastic shell.  The engine's motor is cheap, won't slow-start but jumps, won't run slowly, won't stop slowly but jerks to a halt.  The cars are too light #they feel like an empty egg shell) and easily derail.  The controller only has one DC circuit and one AC and a poor potentiometer type twist throttle that is hard to regulate.  The track is very phoney-looking black molded plastic and code 100 rail.  Code 100 has very tall metal rails that are easier to manufacturer carelessly and hold trains well but look far too tall for scale.  If you "get into it" you won't re-use this track but instead you'll want some code 83 track or to hand lay your own code 70 or 55.  Still, the track and the rest of this set is so cheap, you can't beat it to have something almost 'disposable' to get started with and learn all the hard lessons.  It's like learning to drive in a beater.

The LL set I have doesn't have the plastic road bed.  This is a big improvement for durability in play.  Without the plastic road bed, you have to nail the track to a foam or cork road bed on a sheet of MDF or something or the track will easily break.  The plastic road bed is, of course, completely phoney for scale modeling and is a concession to the toy aspect of this product.  For a toy, I like the Fisher Price Trackmaster trains better.  They're bullet proof, both the engines and the track.  The durability is amazing and yet they're slightly bigger and better detailed than the wooden railways and less expensive.  I do prefer wooden railways for their craftsmanship though, particularly the older Swedish made Brio and the modern Thomas ones.  Another awesome toy to check out is the Lego trains.  They're quite costly with the power options but have two big advantages for play in that they're able to be totally customized, and they integrate with the whole Lego play system.

So their your have it.  If you want to try scale model railroading, this LL set is a cheap start and you'll learn plenty on your way to a rather sophisticated endeavor.  If you're looking for a toy, try Trackmaster for children 6 and under, and Lego trains for older children.  The play value is far better with either of those.  Of course, when I was six, I had to have the 'real' thing.  I got an N scale model and loved it.  If your child is attracted to the scale realism, no mere 'toy' will suffice.
summary: Perfect to test scale or HO toys with kids

This game blew me away, with its amazing art and figures, its epic fantasy feel, and interesting and unique mechanics. Before I go on, I must say that this is not a game for those who do not like rules!! There are essentially two rulebooks; one is a game walkthrough and the other gets into more of the details of the rules as well as the scenarios, and each of them is about 20 pages long! However, I had one of the most gratifying board game experiences once I started to grasp them as well as the flow of the game. The mechanics of the game are not hard to learn, there is just a lot of moving parts and a lot to know. The first scenario really helps you understand what is going on.

I just have to say it felt epic! I have only played one scenario, and I played it solo (to get a grasp of the rules before teaching it to others), but I really enjoyed it and I felt like there was so much depth to the game. This game is truly unique; I have yet to play a fantasy game like it. It is not a dungeon crawler like Descent. Instead it is a game of recruiting army units, pillaging villages, using magic to power special abilities, fighting monsters in dungeons, overtaking cities and keeps and exploring (you lay tiles and actively build your world). You power your actions and movements with cards and magic. While all of this is going on you are leveling up your character and developing new skills. Many fantasy games have aspects of these, but the scope of this game is part of what makes it so unique. I highly recommend it if you are not afraid of rules and taking time to understand the game.

I compared other rock/gem assortments and by far I believe that this is the highest quantity of rocks you will get for your money. The rocks are in a simple ziploc bag that comes in a very small cardboard box. No air in there to fill with inflated bags or other packing material. The added bonus of the meteorite, that interacts with the magnetic hematite, put this over the top for me. reviewText:
SUMMARY (for those who won't read far):
As others have stated, this kitchen is small (my 17m son is 32" high, and he's the perfect height for it), it takes HOURS to assemble (we're talking 5+), and the plastic sink parts don't feel as high quality as the rest of the kitchen.

The Pros:
This kitchen is freaking beautiful. It's solid wood with metal hinges -- really well made.  They are a million screws, hinges, bolts, etc (see pic), and the lengthy assembly process includes about an hour of attaching all the hardware.  The company includes a bunch of extra hardware, too.

The final product weighs 47 lbs -- sturdy and solid. It also comes with a strap to attach it to the wall, which I'd suggest if you have a climber like I do.

My son loves this kitchen. He makes beeping noises as he presses the microwave buttons, and he loves to pretend to drink water from the faucet.  The sink is a bit small, so it won't fit large plates, pots, or pans. The phone is a cute touch, and my son loves to talk on it as he plays.  The doors are a bit hard to open for a tiny guy like mine, but he gets them open with some effort.

All in all, I would suggest this kitchen over most others I've seen, but I'd suggest you pay someone else for the assembly (or have at least two movies to watch while you do it). Oh -- and you MUST have a power tool (drill or screwdriver) with an allen wrench & phillips head attachment.

Cute bell for your swing set. I mounted at the top of the Swing n Slide cargo net so the Grandkids could ring it when they climb to the top of the net. Super easy to install, comes with two cheap little screws to mount the bell holder (I used heavier screws and tossed the ones that came with it).  Unscrew the acorn nut on the bell, slide the bell bolt through the hole on the bell holder, reinstall the acorn nut and tighten. Takes less than 2 minutes.

reviewText:
We got this for our two boys and it's awesome! We've used it 4 times now, with it running for 20+ minutes each time. Batteries are still going strong.

It is loud, but I can deal with that and the kids don't care. Does make me want a radio in the bathroom, though, just to drown it out a bit. Not really because of the volume, but because of the constant drone. But come on, it's not like it has a muffler. It's a cheap toy!

It goes through a lot of soap and we used up the little bottle of bubbles it came with in the first 2 1/2 baths. But then, we're using it a lot, so that's ok. I poured half water and half Mr. Bubbles into and it did ok. Real bubble solution worked better. I'm sure a little bit of dish soap and water would be fine, but the dish soap I have is almond extract soap and it didn't work.

As for the water-proofing everyone is complaining about, mine seems to be submersible! While we tried the almond dish soap in various ratios with water, I rinsed it out really well between experiments, totally putting it under the faucet. It didn't even occur to me to be careful about the battery compartment. But it's doing just fine! However, I wouldn't go throwing it into the tub and I'll be more careful in the future. But maybe some people just didn't have it closed tightly or something. Or maybe they're making them with a better seal now. Who knows.

The big on/off button on the front is easy to use and my 1 year old and 2 1/2 year old figured it out in the first bath. I'm pleased to see that so far the suction cup has held up to their frequent slamming.

Bottom line is, it's not a high-end toy. But it's well built and works great for what it is and for what you're spending. Just enjoy it for that. My only real complaint is that it's ugly.  ;)  It's be nice if it was a little animal or a trendy design or something like that.
ITEM OF EXCEPTIONALLY EXCELLENT QUALITY, GREAT ITEM, GOOD PRICE PRODUCT, DETAILED, WORKS VERY WELL, LOVE THE ITEM, RECOMMEND IT ! A++++++++

As soon as I bought this game, my friends and I played it twice. Even if you are already familiar with Risk, some of the new rules might be challenging to learn. However, the new rules generally make the game much more fun. For example, commanders are more effective at attacking, commander cards add new strategies for winning, and the oceans and even the moon can be your battleground.
For people new at strategic war games, the new game might seem a little too complex, but the game contains rules for playing with the original "classic" Risk rules, although with different-looking armies.
If you're a fan of strategic war games, and especially a fan of Risk, you will greatly enjoy this game.
P.S. I gave this game 2 stars for educational value because it encourages strategic thinking but does not really teach anything aside from diplomatic skills. I gave this game 3 stars for durability because after playing the game twice, nothing broke, but all the pieces are plastic, so IMO it's only a matter of time. Also, the tray that holds the plastic pieces is made of a kind of paper-board, so it's not as durable as plastic or styrofoam (such as in "Shogun", a.k.a. "Samurai Swords").
summary: More complex and more fun than the original

I do wish the case was little bit sturdier but it still looks new today (my daughter takes care of her toys exceptionally well). The video was sub-par but there are many YouTubers that teach magic and she was able to use this set to perform some of those magic tricks.

Overall, it's a great beginner set and the included box makes keeping the magic accessories and many more that you'll probably get all in one place.

reviewText:
The good:

Simple, straight-forward nerf gun. I didn't want anything that needed batteries or had lots of moving parts in order to minimize risk of it breaking. The darts go pretty far and are fairly accurate; I easily hit my sister from about 20 to 25 feet away. Even if you're close the darts don't hurt all that much on impact (though the sound is still a little startling and the anticipation can still make you flinch). Great for 20-somethings of all ages and genders to enjoy and indulge in their childhood desires of having a nerf war.

The bad:

Occasionally my Strongarm misfires (I'd say once every 10 to 12 shots), but it's not a big deal for casual play. Just push the dart back in (usually it comes out partly) and move the revolving chamber to line up the dart with the chamber.
summary: Simple, no-nonsense nerf gun. Occasional misfire, but still very fun.

reviewText: Cute, easy to roll, and made of recycled material the Green Toys Elephant is perfect for very young children. It has a handle at the top that makes it easy to push.  The grey and pink colors are perfect for an elephant.  The elephant even has his trunk up for good luck.  It can be used in many make-believe games helping with both motor and language skills.

It is a solid starter set.  If you play a Seto Kaiba v. Yugi Muto team, then you can have a balanced match of 300 points.  In fact, I've taken the Yugi Muto team and used them against my friends with impressive results.  Blue-Eyes White Dragon and the Dark Magician are good ranged fighters, but everyone else is all close combat.  Breaker is pretty solid too and the Hitotsu-Me Giant also has Spellbinding Circle and Ring of Magnetism abilities that mimic the ones in the card game.  Des Feral Imp and Feral Imp are also included.  The maps included are Pegasus's Castle which has three levels of elevation with a little bit of hindering and blocking terrain.  On the other side, is the Duelist Kingdom map and is a forest area with a considerable amount of hindering terrain.  It also includes item tokens, dice, an abilities sheet, and a rulebook.
Exactly what it is. Packaged well.

Nice concept. When I saw the photo of this baby on Amazon, I knew I had to have her for my daughter's 3rd birthday! She was beautiful and came with all of the accessories which were also too cute! We got her and I don't really think she looks like the photo at all. The real life doll is definitely not as cute and I'm not the only one who has noticed. :/

The hair is kind of weird. Let's just say we encourage my daughter to keep the hat on. She's a bit over-stuffed around the lower belly, but then has skinny little arms and legs - not life-like in my opinion. I had bought some real baby clothes for her to wear and they won't fit because this doll's belly is too big! I'll have to buy some bigger ones and I'm sure they'll end up being too long.

Also, most notably, when we received this doll, she was missing pieces from the box. Just as well, the Velcro is already coming unthreaded from the onesie at the bottom. We've had the doll "in use" since July 6th (just 15 days) and my daughter is actually quite careful with her. I just feel like for an $90 doll, that's unacceptable. I'm a bit concerned to see how the doll even holds up. I had truly hoped that this would be "the doll" - my daughter's life-long favorite from her parents, but the quality makes me question if it'll last through her play years!! Our cheapie $10 dolls from the store seem to hold up better.

That said, my daughter has played with her every day since getting her. This is currently her favorite toy. To see how happy my daughter is with this doll is not worth returning it for how ugly or "falling apart" it is. (Again, although she's been played with daily, my daughter IS careful with her!!)

All-in-all, if I had to buy over again, I'd definitely get a real-feel doll, but it would NOT be this one!

This is one of those toys that would be fun for a very specific age range of kids, I think. It takes quite a while to put together, so younger kids might give up or get frustrated before they can get everything connected. But the size and colorful design of this set appeals to the younger kids maybe more so than older kids (teens).

My son is 14 and has a ton of patience for these types of toys, so he did enjoy working on this. He worked on it on and off for the better part of an evening. His twin sister is a more typical teen and wasn't interested in playing with it at all, at least until it was together. The recommended age ranges vary, with Amazon saying 6 to 15 years old, and the manufacturer saying it's recommended for ages 6 and up. Unless you have a very patient younger child, I'd say ages 10-13 would be the range that would enjoy this set the most. Not that other kids wouldn't have fun with it too, but the design my be a little too toy-like for older teens, but may take too much time to assemble for very young kids. It's a great kit for kids in the "tween" age range.
summary: Lengthy assembly but toy like design would cause it to appeal to kids in a very specific age range

reviewText: Great activity book. My pre-teen kiddos love these.

Hot Wheels hit a home run with this starter set. Construction is simple, the tracks are durable and, most importantly, the toy is user-friendly. Tested with a three-year old boy, the track worked perfectly and showed no signs of pulling away from the wall (Visions of the old suction cup attachments were blown away by these 3M Command Strips, which stick the base of the tracks in place.)

For adults, the big news is that you no longer have to play on your knees! Elevating the track on the wall not only clears the floor (saving someone from that dreaded barefoot step on a jagged car part) but also allows the child to move around the track more easily.

I wish they had invented these tracks when I was a boy.

Rating: Five stars.
summary: Hot Wheels gets you off your knees and lets you play on the wall!

Anyway... This is a must for any collection. Don't be fooled because of lack of colors or detail. This is just like one in TV show. Its plain in TV show, its plain figure. I don't see it as plain or boring like others I've read say.
Figure includes black design on body and detail around face for eyes. Most possible of all figures to be released yet. Featured with the figure the Loogie has a weapon as well fits in either hand. Very detailed weapon can be used as laser gun or as blade depending on how hold it.
But, figure also includes Vrak's Zombat as well. You get basically two toys in one. Zombat is very accurate. Black with white eye. Shape is great and includes nice black paint scheme. Zombat can be attached to either back of Loogie or on its feet. Very cool feature for kids when playing with toys or collectors to display figure.
As with all Megaforce toys each one includes a collectible Character Card. This toy includes the Loogie Card. Very cool card that you can scan with your phone to watch a video or put in your Gosei Morpher and hear a Vileness toon.

reviewText: This is an absolutely adorable and engaging toy. Inside the bucket your child will find easy to grab pieces that represent half of an animal. When placed together into the lid of the bucket these pieces create "mashed up" animals. When the animal pieces are pressed into the lid the toy plays sounds representative of each half of the animal (for example, a horsedog, a pigcow, etc.). The toy also plays fun farm-themed music. I love that the toy is compact and all of the pieces are stored inside the bucket, making this one easy to take along on trips to visit friends and family. Great product!

The first thing my son did was take apart the entire track (of course) and he loves to throw those pieces around everywhere.  So really, he just plays with the main tower and the 2 autos - he likes that the smaller one makes all kinds of noises when you go over certain spots, but he really likes that the smaller one can go into a through the larger one - that entertains him the most.  I definitely think he will grow to enjoy this toy more, but I'd wait to purchase it until your child is a little bit older.

Edited:  My son is now 2 years old and he LOVES this toy..... so yes..... it's much better suited for a child over the age of 2 (in my opinion).  He no longer breaks the track apart..... well sometimes..... but he now plays with it the way it was intended to be played with - and it's one of his favorites.

reviewText:
On the Brink is an outstanding expansion to an already great game.

The good
* New role cards add some more variety to play
* The petri dishes make handling the virus cubes WAY more convenient
* the smaller sized pawns make the board much more manageable
* the new rules for special events (2 per player) and the new cards add more variety to gameplay

The bad
* There's a lot of pieces to this game.  Neither box (the original nor this one) holds all the pieces in a satisfactory way

The unknown
* We haven't played with the bioterrorist yet.  It looks like it'll add some great "Scotland Yard" like fun to the game, but I just don't know yet.
* We haven't played with the virulent or mutated strains yet (Primarily play with younger sons (8 & 5), so we don't want it to be _too_ hard for them)

Summary
This is a great expansion.  If you like/love Pandemic, this expansion adds more of everything there is to love, without becoming overwhelming.
summary: Outstanding expansion to a great game

There are a few great additions to the KoT gameplay that make KoNY a worthy purchase. In addition, if you are new to the King series, New York is a better place to start. It gives you the ability to play KoT (with a tiny bit of ingenuity) or move up to the full rules.

I was introducing my kids to the game and taught them the KoT rules so they could grasp the gameplay easier and then added the KoNY rules.

Now as for the game - this game is a game I can play with my kids, my wife, or my buddies. It's easy to introduce to new gamers and has enough depth for experienced gamers to stay interested. It is a great game full of fun and surprises.

If you have the room for this, the garage is a "must have" item for any hot wheels fan.  My daughter was asking for it to be assembled every hour she was awake until it was assembled.  Knowing it would take awhile, my husband assembled it on the weekend before she got up in the morning.  It took about 45 minutes.

As fun as this set is, be sure you have the room as this garage takes up even more than the garage itself.  If you connect it to other sets with the tracks as well as the track included...you're not even including the space needed for the car to spin off the track.  That said, it is something to set up and leave where you build it.  Most homes probably will not have the dedicated room to give this toy justice inside but maybe outside on a porch if not inside.

Assembly depends on both complete parts and how well you read the instructions.  My husband thought the levels were all the same and didn't see them already labeled as a color.  Hence the parking space colored numbers don't match the floor color but it still works.  It would have been nice to see the parking numbers already attached to avoid that error.  The other problem we encountered was a grey part that holds down the orange slide to the green tower was missing.  This slows the car down the ramp some so it doesn't usually get enough speed to get past the shark.

My daughter spent most of the first day it was assembled playing with this toy.  It simply has so many parts that she was always trying something new and enjoyed pushing the buttons.  You will need 3 aa batteries as they do not come with the toy.  I do wish the sound came with a volume control beyond simply on or off.  It simply is a loud toy that can be heard from one end of the house to the other and one of the sounds is a fire siren.

Overall, if your child...or even adult loves hot wheels...you have a family toy for many hours of play.  Hopefully your toy will come with all parts and be sure you read the assembly instructions carefully...my husband tried to skip a few which is why our level colors don't match.
summary: A toy to keep you busy for hours

reviewText:
I am homeschooling my 6-year-old, and these blocks are PERFECT for our math lessons. We initially had paper blocks in 1, 10, and 100 sizes, but my daughter wasn't understanding. The plastic blocks made everything come together, and we're breezing through our lessons now. We're working on concepts including place value, 3- and 4-digit numbers, and greater than/less than. The blocks make everything so easy! We have used them in every single lesson so far this year.

Another point to note is that my daughter plays with these blocks during her free time. She loves to stack and count them. She makes stairs out of them and plays just like she would with Legos.

I really debated about buying these blocks, but I'm glad I did. They're sturdy enough to keep them for my younger daughter, as well.

The other reviews were spot on.  These felt hats are well made and fit everyone from children to adults!  There were no inconsistent sewing flaws, no rips, and clean.  Two months later and they are still one piece.  This was an excellent buy for the price considering a local party store wanted the same price for paper pirate hats!
summary: Inexpensive as paper ones but better!

This game is pretty fun and much easier then dealing with the board game, counting money, dealing out cards. I give it 4 stars for a few reasons: narrations and the background music are repetitive and make you want to slap someone after a while. Also, you can't speed up the turns, which I would like to do for the AI. Just let me know what happens, I don't want to watch the game count out all the movements on the board. You could spend as much time playing this as the real monopoly!

I like the options to unlock boards (although that does nothing to change the game) and the options to select different game plays to shorten the game.

Another reason this game has 4 stars is because it causes way too many arguments over if we should select the option that you win money when you land on the free space. You should totally get the money!

I got this game for $5 at a Borders store in NYC that was going out of business. I brought it to a game Meetup. The idea is to try to match other players answers to the matching topics. Each player gets a different color paddle to write their answers on. There were four of us playing. The first topic was OLD BOOK. We all said The Bible and scored.

It's an easy game to play, but it can take a while to match an answer. I played two games of it and won both. In addition to writing an answer, the special die has two special spots. One has you teaming up with another player to come up with one answer between you, and another spot has you drawing your answer instead of writing it. We all matched on Superman when we drew an EARLY SUPERHERO.

The most common answer said scores one point for all who said it. If two answers tie, both answers score. It takes eight matching answers to win. A fun game and up to six can play. The one drawback is the markers which can dry up or wear out easily. I bought matching color markers at a stationery store that work better. I use these same markers for Wits and Wagers, Say Anything and Truth Be Told. It might be worth the investment if this turns out to be a popular game among you and others you know.

As someone who's loved introducing my kids to the universes of my childhood (transformers, X-men, etc), I was excited to see them react to this transformer.  As it happens, they played with it pretty consistently -- for about three days.  Then it lost its luster. It comes out sometimes now when playing with other action figures, but hasn't remained any kind of a favorite.  My kids' complaints covered a bunch of issues, mostly around the toy's quality.  Transformation between modes isn't nearly fluid as older Transformers toys.  Middling design contributes to these issues.  The plastic feels insubstantial, especially in the case of the weapons, but with the OP body as well.  The same is true with the "spinning cannon" an idea that was good in concept, but poor in execution.

At $50, this is an expensive toy.  I'd expect more for my money.
summary: Hard to transform, not great quality

(Update is at the bottom of the review) Two of my boys (roughly ages 8 and 10) and I opened this lab together and made some slime with it - my review is based on this experience.  (Note: you may have to purchase borax, cabbage, white glue, and a few other relatively common ingredients to make some of the recipes.)

PROS:
-It is relatively easy to set up and doesn't have many small parts that could get lost.
-The instruction booklet is colorful and the recipes are straightforward and (mostly) simple.
-The pieces of the kit aren't flimsy; they don't feel like they will break (though the dome is thin plastic so one has to be careful).
-My kids enjoyed it because it was "hands on" - they could get "dirty" and learn about the slime from experience.

CONS:
-The vibrator/machine is super noisy.  We had to talk loudly to hear over it; it annoyed other people in the room.
-The spoon for measuring makes a mess because it has two compartments in the one side - and the two compartments are almost bigger than the bowl used for mixing.
-Though the booklet is colorful and the recipes are easy to follow, some of the other details and notes in it are not always easy to follow (some of the comments in the booklet are pretty scientific - like those of polymers and cohesion).

To summarize, this is a neat kit although I wasn't "blown away" by it.  If your kids are not too interested in things like this, it might not capture their attention for long.  However, if you have kids who are interested in basic chemistry or making things like this, I'm guessing they'd like it.  And, as with other science kits like this, it does make a mess!  But the mess is worth it when you see the kids having fun and learning at the same time.

UPDATE: Our kids did play with this for awhile, but once they made the recipes, they lost interest.
summary: Neat Kit - Good For Kids Who Like Experimenting! (UPDATE)

My child loves super heroes and was really excited for this doll. The doll is adorable in person - her skin, hair, boots and cape are a soft micro plush material; her outfit is a smooth satin. Her mask and star are embroidered on as are her facial features and the bows holding her pigtails are actual tied ribbon. She stands approximately 13.5" tall and her all plush body makes her quite huggable. Unfortunately the way her outfit is crafted leaves a lot to be desired. The fabric along the hem of the cape and skirt is rough cut and there are several glaring sewing defects. The material puckers in several places along the hem where fabric wasn't laid flat and had gathered on the skirt and there are a couple of places where uneven stitching made with a thick white thread is visible. The seam up her back is rough and puckered as well. It looks as though perhaps the doll was hand stitched in places to repair defects made in the manufacturing process. The doll I received also has a hole in the back where a seam was missed behind the cape and stuffing was coming out of this hole (I will be attaching photos to show these defects). I'm no sewing expert but I plan to pull seams and hems and attempt to do a little repair work but this shouldn't even be a consideration with a doll at this price point. I was planning on buying the adorable male companion doll, North American Bear Company Baby Hero Boy Doll but if this is the level of quality one can expect from this company I think I will have to pass. Unless you are handy with a needle and don't mind a little repair work, I sadly cannot recommend this product.

This is my first experience with LeapPad products. Myself and my 8 year old son tested it. If your child already has another tablet type product, they will probably find it more fun/interesting then this one.  The LeapPad works fine, I had no issues with applications, stylus, or speed.  It is probably the selection of games avialable in the app stores, compared to the LeapFrog,  Also, this is rated 24 months to age 9, my son totally felt that the educaitonal games were to easy and that this was more for a "baby" - his words.  This device is so much more limited.  I understand that it is proabably about 1/2 the price of the major brand name tablets, but not sure it is for anyone over the age of 6 (in my opinion).  I can imagine that if a child has never used a name brand tablet that they might find this product far more interesting.  But most children have had access to these products in friends, family and school to know the difference.

The apps for LeapPad are more expensive then in the name brand app stores.  Some of the aps for LeapPad were as high as $35.  what if your child doesn't like the game, you are out $35!  There are some features on this product he will probably use and play with, but I don't see it taking the place of his other tablet or game systems.

The two games taht came with the platinum package was also - in his words - girl games.  another thing to consider - unless they know their demographic is young girls.

Bottom line, I think it is well made, just maybe for younger kids and if they don't have access to other brand tablets.

It stops the motor from turning, then he pulls his hand out and watches it start back up.  We have not had any trouble with the motor as some others have. reviewText:
In King of Tokyo, each player takes on the role of one of several monsters attempting to destroy Tokyo.  But, though Tokyo is fairly defenseless, the other monsters are contesting you, as they want to be the ultimate destroyer of the city!  Each turn, you run six dice.  You can keep any number of them that you want, and you can re-roll the other dice up to two more times.  Based on those dice, you can do a few things - with claws, you attack whichever monster is in Tokyo (or, if you are in Tokyo, you attack everyone else), with hearts, you heal damage (unless you're in Tokyo), if you get three matching numbers, you score that many victory points, and if you roll lightning bolts, you gain energy.  Whenever you attack someone in Tokyo, they must decide if they are staying in Tokyo, or leaving.  If they leave, then you are forced to take over Tokyo - which gives you one point, while making you a target.  But, for each of your turns that you are still in Tokyo, you gain two points.  At the end of each turn, you may also use your accumulated energy to buy upgrades.  The first person to score twenty points wins.  Or, since you're awesome monsters and fighting each other and such, the last monster standing wins!!!  (This is actually how most of my games end.)

BoardGameReviewsByJosh is spot on with his review above.

reviewText:

Game Overview: Dimension is a puzzle game where you are working with five sets of colored spheres with three spheres of each color given to each player.  A set of six cards are played which will give you directions on how you are to build your tower of spheres.  You earn points by meeting the different objectives, using each sphere color in your final tower and by the number of spheres that were used.  Fail to meet any of the objectives on the card and you lose points.  All of this occurs in this fast paced game as an hourglass timer counts down the time.

Box Contents:  Top notch quality is found here.  From the 60 heavy plastic spheres to the stands that hold the spheres that you build upon.  You also have multiple cardboard tokens which allow you to keep track of your score.  The box insert holds everything nicely and baggies are included, which is a must to keep the spheres in their place.  It also has compartments designed specifically for the hourglass timer and the cards.

Clarity of Rules: The rules are on a large four page color manual that does an excellent job at explaining the rules and provides detailed explanations on each card that may come into play.

Game Play:  To begin play, all players place their spheres on their playing area.  Six cards are then drawn from the deck.  These cards provide the directions on how to play the spheres to meet the rounds objectives.  There are seven types of cards that you will see throughout the game.  1.  Being able to use only a certain number of spheres of a specific color. 2.  Spheres of certain colors must touch somewhere in your tower. 3.  Spheres of certain colors must not touch in your tower.  4.  Spheres of certain colors can not be played above any other spheres .  5.  Spheres of certain colors can not be played below any other spheres.  6. You must have more spheres of one color than another color in your tower.  7.  You must have a combined total of four spheres between two of the colors.  To begin, you simply flip over the hourglass timer, which gives you approximately one minute to complete your tower based on the cards that were played.  Once the timer ends, you add up your points for that round.  Initially, you get a point for every sphere you used.  The top score here is 11, which signifies a full tower.  However, you may not always get this based on the cards that came into play.  You next go through the cards that were played.  If you succeeded, you do not earn any points.  If you failed to meet that objective, you lose two points.  If you met all of the card objectives and you used each sphere color, you earn a bonus token.  The number of bonus tokens you earn will count towards your final score after all rounds are played. The bonuses can vary from -6 to 6 points.  You repeat this for a total of six rounds before the winner is determined.

Replay Ability:  There is plenty of replay ability here until you master this game, which is very possible.  Our oldest son has already gotten to that point where he maximize his points for each round/game.  Once that happens, the intrigue of the game becomes less and less.

Appropriate Audience: 8+ is appropriate.  However,  you could probably go a little younger since your game play is based on how the spheres are to be played and the fact that there is not any text on the cards.  You just need to ensure they won't get frustrated with not meeting the different criteria that may come up from the cards since you lose points for failing.

What We Liked/Didn't Like: This is a great family game and really makes everyone think and act quickly.  As a parent, it is fun to watch the kids quickly solve these puzzles.  It is a little frustrating when cards come up that contradict themselves.  However, the directions do address this by telling you that the player can decide which one to use and then take the negative points on the other, which is how we play.  The other options provided in the rules manual allow you to draw a new card and to place the contradicting card back into the deck or to remove certain types of cards up front.  This seems to be a flaw of the game and you shouldn't have to remove cards from the game to make it work for all situations.

reviewText: Love it! Great for Pirate parties :)

It's a nice set. "Santa" brought it to me today, and I had planned to build it together with my 7 year old but after watching for a few minutes, he decided it was too complicated and left me alone to build.  ;-)

I'm glad that this was my second K'nex set (last Christmas, I received and built the Supersonic Swirl Set), because while this one was a bit easier to build, the instructions were more difficult to make out, and it helped greatly that I knew from last year how to put two connectors together to make corners etc. Someone who has never worked with K-nex before might be puzzled and wish for close up pictures for some of the instructions.

My main problem was that one of the long blue "sticks" was missing. Without it, the frame for the tower wouldn't come together, or the whole construction would become unstable (if I "stole" one from the bottom to finish the tower). Both was unacceptable. I was lucky in that I was able to "borrow" a few pieces from one of my son's projects (two red sticks plus a red connector = the length of the blue stick), so I was able to make it work, but I had to disassemble something that he built and he didn't like that.....and what do the people do who don't have additional sets in the house?

So on the whole, it's a cute finished product and it was fun to build, but it does have some flaws.....I would not recommend it as a starter set ;-)
summary: Nice but missing a crucial part + instructions not always clear

-The game makers "thoughtfully" provide a sponge you can soak in water...You know, just in case you don't want the mess of whipped cream.
-The hand is upside down.  It's odd and the kids get pretty vexed when it doesn't look right.
-USE COTTON!  It's a brilliant sub for whipped cream.  I simply found a small paper plate, made a large tape donut, and loaded it up with cotton balls.  Problem solved.

All that being said, the kids had a ball with it, including my almost 3 YO.  It's a fun game for a young crowd who typically has the attention span of a goldfish.

Here's a fun and flexible way to learn fractions for kids of all ages. Who doesn't love pizza, right? Kids relate to it because pizza naturally uses fractions.

I appreciate a kid-friendly way to teach fractions that's not cake, pie or candy. I'm not a big fan of teaching or playing with desserts because somehow it always leads to the kids wanting candy - the power of suggestion?!

Seven game instructions are included, and the possibilities expand from there.  When kids play these games, they build a concrete sense of how fractions are parts of a whole, fraction equivalents, addition and subtraction. Pizza naturally lends itself to word problems and everyday application, and there are several problem solving activities included.

The pieces are made of a sturdy cardboard and stand up to a good amount of kid use. This is a great way to play and have fun while teaching and reinforcing fractions!
summary: An excellent way to play and have fun while learning fractions

reviewText: Bought these as well as another brand for many kids this Christmas. While they both work flawlessly, this brand seemed to be a bit "sturdier". Great for our kids to operate, and they make good snow cream scoops!

Over the past two years, I have really become quite the gamer. I now purchase about ten games a year and I am always looking to try out something new. I try to pick up any new games that I can to give them a spin, and this game looked to be quite a bit different from other games I currently own. Most of my games are strategy games, hidden role games, card drafting games, miniatures games, or assorted types of party games. I have very few spatial orienting or dexterity games, so this was truly something new for me to try. So, after a couple of plays, here are my thoughts:

1. Components: Quality is high. The plastic balls have a nice heft to them and are surely sturdy enough to stand up to many plays and falls. All of the cardboard components are plenty thick and were cleanly cut so it was easy to punch out the pieces of each. The cards are printed on a high-quality stock of paper. Instructions are clear, illustrated, and free of errors. My very slight complaint about the components is this: I wish there were a few more small plastic baggies included in the box so that I could sort the many small cardboard components and store them all separate from one another. I happened to have a few small plastic zip-lock bags left over from another game so I was still able to sort them as I wished, but it would have been nice to have a few of these included.

2. Mechanics: This game features some interesting mechanics. The game is all about proper positioning of the colored balls: which color is touching which, how many you can use, where things must go or where they can't go. All of this takes place under the impetus of time, too. This game has little to do with strategy or deduction, yet it is very analytical in nature. There is always a best way to accomplish your tasks, but figuring out what that way is under a short time constraint makes the game more fun (or more frustrating - depending on how your brain works). The game is very easy to learn, yet can be difficult to master.

3. Fun: I found this game to be entertaining, yet it isn't one I am likely to pull out very often. My son liked it pretty well, but the other three members of my family didn't care for it. They found it too difficult and pretty much resigned themselves to losing the game every time they play it. They did not find it fun and will not want to play it again anytime soon. Because of this, I had to give it a lower rating. Though it could still be categorized as a family game, I kind of think you'd have a hard time finding too many households where everyone would like it. This game definitely appeals to certain types of people, and - unfortunately - most of the members of my family are not that type of family. Since two of us thought it was OK and three of us didn't like it, this one may not stay in my collection for long.
summary: A very original game that will probably mostly appeal to a niche audience rather than receive widespread appeal...

My 3 yo son got this from Santa, and it became his favorite gift. It's manageable enough that he can bring it with him everywhere, including the car, and I can tuck it easily in my bag when we're on the go. This is an exact replica of the JD mower that my husband bought at Lowes several years ago. The seat tilts forward, and the wheels and steering wheel turn responsively.

My only complaint, and I've had this issue with both of the ones we've owned (I returned the first one), is with the cart. The cart tilts backward, and it's actually possible without using a lot of force to invert the rod that connects to the hitch on the mower so it swings 180 degrees. It's not meant to go that far, but with the way it's constructed, it can do so with minimal force. With the first one we owned. the rod broke off from the cart completely rendering the cart unusable. With the second one, the rod has been inverted already and a piece of metal at the end of the rod is warped (where it connects to the cart's bed), but it hasn't broken off yet. It's only a matter of time until it does. To avoid this, I have a rule for my son to be very gentle with the cart and not tilt it. It's frustrating that cart was meant to tilt, but if you do, it can break.

I'd be happier if this item was a little cheaper and included the mower only. All things aside, the mower itself makes a wonderful gift for a little John Deere fan.
summary: Lawnmower is study, but the cart isn't

I am going to leave the technical portion of the review to those that know more about drone.  I will instead focus on the simplicity and fun portion! I purchased this for my 15 year old son. He had his laptop out and watched all the videos on their website.  He assembled it by himself and it was perfect.  (You might want to start charging the battery first!!  Waiting the hour seemed like forever! )

  Prior to this, he has only flown the Hubsan H107C.  I know that the Hubsan gave him a foundation for flying and the basic skills before he took to the sky with the DJI!  We upgraded because he really wanted to use his GoPro.

  His first flight was flawless - it took a couple minutes for the controller and drone to recognize each other, but that was a short wait.  He kept it low and close until he got the hang of the controller.  Can I insert a WOW right here? WOW.  He hit the "Return to Home" (RTH) button and you could see the drone stop, think and return.....hover overhead and then slowly begin coming down.

  Hints and tips for a 1st time user:  Definitely WATCH the videos and read the advice of others in these reviews. You will learn something for sure!  Buy an extra battery and extra props! It does come with extra props, but I have a feeling we will need more!

  We absolutely LOVE the DJI Phantom and look forward to owning  future releases down the road!
summary: Easy enough for a 15 year old to assemble and fly - 1 - 2 - 3 !

Of the Funko My Little Pony line, Funko really got two ponies right - Cadance was the first, and her handsome hubby Shining Armor was the second.  Shining Armor is very well sculpt, has little to no paint issues, and he looks absolutely dashing in his wedding outfit.  The sculpt of SA is very well done and my pony had no blemishes or pock marks.  His coloring is uniform throughout, and the areas that were painted had no bleeding or discoloration.  His cutie mark is also very cleanly done, and the transfer was perfect.

The detailing on SA is great - his jacket is probably the most detailed item in the MLP Funko line and they nailed it.  There's really nothing bad to say about this figure.  He's well balanced, beautifully colored, and very show accurate.  SA and Cadance are probably my favorite pony sculpts in the Funko line to date - they're just that well done.
summary: He'll Be Your B.B.B.F.F! (Big Brother Best Friend Forever!)

reviewText: We purchased this wagon for our grandson's first birthday.  He has a 3 year old sister and they will be able to ride together for several years.  He loves his wagon!  Right now he just likes to sit in it and play with toys.  He can dive and roll in and out by himself.  This is the third Radio Flyer Voyager Canopy Wagon I have purchased in the past 4 years.  I have two other families of grandchildren for whom they were birthday gifts also.  The families use them when going to the park or to the farmer's market.  One family has used it in the local community children's parade for two years running.  The wagon is constructed of sturdy plastic with rounded corners that are unlikely to cause serious bumps for little ones or damage to furniture or the interior of the car when they are loaded up.  They roll well on pavement, gravel, and grass. The canopy comes off easily, but is nice for sun protection when needed. Two children can easily ride on the seats, probably up to about 6 or 7 years old.  They have handy cup holders and are easy to hose off if they get sticky or dirty.  My family members have been very pleased with this product.  I'll probably be getting another in a year or two for my other son's family.  Buying from Amazon is the best way to get this product.  Shipping is free and you don't have to search toy stores.  Large items like this are sometimes hard to find in stock in the stores.  We have been pleased with the product and Amazon service.
summary: Birthday Wagon for 1 year old Grandson!

reviewText: This is a fun game that requires kids to make quick decisions. The object of the game is to get your pirate "safe on the island"  with the most gold coins before the "shark throws you off". If you are thrown off, you are out of the game. On each player's turn, the die is rolled and the player  must quickly decide to either "move forward" that many spaces, or stay on there current mark and opt to collect the amount of coins that corresponds to the die number. This is a fast moving game that certainly "amps them up" so I don't suggest playing before bedtime. My kids are 4 and 6 and perhaps my 4 year-old is a little young for it, but she can certainly join in the fun.
summary: Fun game that requires quick decision-making

I was excited for this toy.  My daughter (4) LOVES the drawing apps on my iPod touch.  I decided to get her this for her birthday.  Without my iPad.. it's just a cool-looking magna-doodle.  Not really great for nearly $40.  WITH the iPad it is not a lot better.  FIrst, you can download the app and use the drawing feature for free without the iCanvas.  If you have the iCanvas you can use the stylus pen or add one of the six shapes that you see in the pictures (the shapes around the outside of the iCanvas board).  You can use your fingers to adjust the size of the shape just like any iPad/iPhone/iPod drawing app. There are also two games you can use within the iCanvas App, a Memory-matching & a game where you toss a ball to a dog (it makes no sense).  The two games will not work without the iPad plugged in.

I don't think this is at all worth it.  My daughter stopped using the pen and used her finger to draw or color within the app.  She continued to use it even after I popped the iPad out.  My iPad has a few versions of memory that she prefers those over the one that came within the iCanvas app.  Neither of us figured out the dog-ball-toss game.

*Other notes:  When you try to go to the "photo roll" within the app, it crashes.  This has happened EVERY time.  It WILL save pictures to the iPad Photos app but you cannot access them from the iCanvas app like it says is possible ( you are suppose to be able to draw on existing pics).  Maybe that will be addressed with an app update later on.  If this were $20, I would have kept it.. but for close to $40... just not worth it.  I am returning this.  I think I will look for a kid-friendly stylus instead.  Hope this helps...

reviewText:
I just received this today... haven't had a chance to actually try it. However this is my fifth tube trainer and third brand of this style of tube trainer that I have purchased in the last year. I have two little ones a year and a half apart, and have used them for both. The first brand I tried was the Swim Tee Trainer.  The second was an Aqua Coach tube trainer.  The reason we keep buying new ones is that we LOVE this style of flotation device, but they keep popping on us from being left in a hot car, or wearing out because of poor design. Last summer my 12 month old could swim around the pool after the second day of swimming with it, and loved it!  They just have to learn how to balance themselves.

The swim Tee trainer had really flimsy material around the tube that got holes in in from just touching things, like the slides at the pool. This happened with both of our tubes. The rubber inner tube, which you would fill  with an air compressor, eventually was bulging horribly out on all sides.  And that was only after less than a month.  On one of our tubes, a hole in the fabric started from just filling the tube up with air.  This brand really didn't last long.  I think a better material would have made a huge difference.

The Aqua Coach tube trainer seemed a lot better, but the tube itself was actually smaller, so it was harder to get on my 3 year old.  We could do it, though, and it really wasn't an issue for us.  However, the safety strap wasn't comfortable long enough for my 3 year old to use.  So, we cut the under strap off, and because the tube was too small to fit over his shoulders, I didn't see any reason to worry about the possibility of him falling through.  This one again had the rubber inner tube filled the same way with an air compressor. I was over-all completely satisfied with this brand. I did have one of these pop while being filled up, and therefore, needed one more.  I wasn't particularly careful to get this exact brand - just careful not to get the swim tee trainer - and ended up now with the Aqua Leisure one.

I ordered this Aqua Leisure tube simply because the price was right and I figured it would be worth a try.  I did like that the strap for the bottom had a clip.  On the past ones I had used, they had Velcro to secure the strap, which I was a little worried would perhaps catch on their swimsuits, though they never did.  I thought it might be nice to try this one with a clip and see if I liked it better.  And I figured I might just cut it off again anyway.  Well, just out of the box, my biggest surprise is that this tube is not a durable rubber inner tube.  Through the fabric, it feels like a plastic inner tube that you buy for a couple dollars at the store. The box claims it is a "rugged inner tube for years of use."  You are not supposed to fill this one with an air compressor.  There are TWO little valves that look like the ones on a beach ball or any other blow up toy.  Strange.  I used my bicycle hand pump to fill it up.  I wasn't sure what to expect... I wasn't sure how it would look round like a tire if there were two air compartments.  Since you can't see the inner tube within the fabric, I was really skeptical.  However, once both compartments were filled, it does look fine.  I'm just not sure there is enough air inside to safely hold my little ones up out of the water the way our other ones do.  I will have to give a follow-up once we give this new one a try.

Update after first use:

The tube is not durable.  It popped after about an hour of normal use by a three year old.  It was a slow leak, and very dangerous since it took us a little bit of time for us to realize what had happened.  He was securely above the surface of the water when we began.  Because of the slow leak, it wasn't immediately obvious there was a problem.  At some point, we noticed he was lower in the water, to a nearly dangerous level, and realized there wasn't enough air anymore in the tube.  Of course we were in the water there with him so he was safe, but had we not been paying close attention, it could have meant him drowning.  We immediately took him out of the water, and tried to refill it with the hand pump.  As I put air in, I could hear air leaking out of the tube somewhere, though I couldn't see where because the tube is covered with fabric.  I am so disappointed in the quality of this tube. I am hoping to get my money back.  I am not familiar with Amazon's returning of a product that has been used, and unfortunately I through the box away prematurely.  The box said "durable"... I should have trusted my gut instinct and returned it before using.  Any one have suggestions of how I proceed to get my money back??

reviewText: My baby from about 4 months onward just wanted my iphone or my husband's android smart phone. She knows a cheap fake when she sees one and this phone, despite its good intentions, is a cheap fake. It's far too thick, big and goofy to be the real deal. My kid is looking at me like, "Come on mom -- really? You're just embarrassing yourself AND me with these feeble attempts at a cell phone switcheroo. Now fork over the iphone".  I wish somebody would make a play phone that looks for all the world like a real smart phone and even makes some noises and has some graphics like one but is safe for a baby to drool and chew on. Nothing too fancy but enough that it tricks an infant. I don't think that's asking a lot -- to fool a baby. I'd seriously pay some good money for it (reasonable, but good money) if it meant I didn't have to constantly clean baby slobber out from where it seeped between the phone screen & protective screen of my $60 Otterbox brick (that my phone is jailed in at present to protect it from my kids). If I don't fork over my phone it's gonna be a full-blown Calgon moment. My husband is an engineer and I keep telling him to design this toy and make us rich but he's far too busy cleaning baby slobber out of his own phone to worry about my get-rich-quick toy ideas. I hope Fisher-Price or somebody else figures out the fix and I'll line up with my credit card like every other smart phone toting parent out there.

reviewText: Pencils are great for my use. I use them for my adult coloring books. A couple of the colors are a little too similar. Also when I got them the center had fallen out, but once I sharpened them they work great.

I'm a big fan of plastic tokens, and these are no exception.  The paint printing on these is really good and has, so far, been  durable and has not worn off.
The broken wall "tokens" (which are actually miniatures) are the best - they are easy to see on the board when the Abominotaur (from the bosses pack) busts through the wall.  Occasionally, when the board gets very crowded, it was difficult to easily see these broken wall areas with the flat cardboard tokens you get in with the bosses pack.  These 3D broken wall minis are much easier to identify on the board.

I gave this four stars instead of five because the red color on the "X" tokens isn't completely consistent.  They are about 90 - 95% there, but if you pay close attention, you can tell the difference between some of these.  This is important because in some scenarios, you are looking for a green or blue "X" on the flip side of the token (which are randomized and placed before the game begins).  These hidden green or blue X's represent finding a key or completing some kind of goal.
But if you can tell by looking at the red "X" side that it has green or blue on the other side due to a slight inconsistency in the color, it's not right.

What I do is I just play the game and not pay attention to the slight differences in red color shade.  Mostly, it works just fine.
summary: Not at all necessary, but fantastic bling!

reviewText: CUTE AND WORKED GREAT. USED AT DISNEY AND KEPT KIDS FROM WANTING THE PRICEY ITEMS AT THE PARADE.

I am fan of the Throne units in Gundam00 so I decide upon grabbing a favorite of the trio: Nena Trinity's Throne Drei.
Unfortunately, there's quite a few setbacks for this model alone and probably for the rest of trio.

Pros:
+ It's quite sturdy and balances fairly well despite its backpack and its heeled feet.
+ The colors are pretty presentable and personally I love the combinations here (Maroon red, muddy brown, and stellar white)
+ Decent articulation
+ Does have her signature GN particle generators.

Cons:
- It lacks a lot of accessories including beam sabers or any options of hands besides the two it comes with.
- The hip portion of the kit is nicely articulated with the legs and its joints, but it is fragile. The rest of the kit is sturdy but there.
- You need to panel line and paint parts of this kit to make it anywhere being appealing to the show's version. Many of the parts as you assemble are mostly one colored and the parts that are suppose to be another, you would have to paint it.
- Drei looks very out of place without her brothers, Zwei and Eins. IMO, you would need all of them to really bring out their presence.
- For a HG and the content (lack of, really), I wouldn't pay even more than $16. I took on this as $28.08, almost $30.

So my verdict; if you plan on assembling the trio and maybe Arche Throne, then sure. Just be ready to paint Drei and probably the rest of them if they do come out like Drei did in its kit. If you're just grabbing Drei just because, then no. Frankly, there are better kits to go and grab at the same price or even cheaper or (more expensive in cases like Kshatriya). I was a bit generous of giving Drei three stars but the kit is just underwhelming. Spend that $30+ (quote of contemporary price of $28.77 right now) on some other kit you've had your eyes on. Nothing to see here.

reviewText:
Slug is the most recent redesign of the Dinobot formerly known as Slag. The Dinobots for Transformers 4 are a bit of a mixed bag. While Slug isn't the top of the heap, there is a lot to like about this Triceratops. The first big thing that old school fans will recognize are the red and purple plates that make up much of Slugs dino form. Each of the new dinobots has its own primary color in the new toyline, from slug to scorn to Snarl. Youll also notice the design choice where Slugs body is much more segmented, in contrast to his G1 likeness. It really pops around his head crest.

In robot mode, Slug is a part of this knight aesthetic that flows from Optimus on down through many of the supporting characters. The dino head splits to become two massive shoulder parts and is even attached with a screw where the eye would be in dino mode, which is a fun choice. I will say Im not overly crazy about the way his tail dangles off the back of the robot mode, but its not horrible. Hes got some nice articulation and looks really slick standing next to both Scorn and Grimlock. If you can pick him up for under twenty dollars, hes an easy add. Much more than that, and Id be inclined to look at some of the other TF4 toys first.
summary: A Dino by any other name...

- the velcro connectors on the tunnel keep getting caught on my daughter's hair. I believe they are there to attach to another tunnel segment, however there is no place to velcro the sticky part to to hide the hooks when not in use. She keeps getting snagged and crying.
summary: Tent material is great but there are a couple flaws

reviewText: Quality of a couple of pieces was a bit disappointing.  I decided to keep it for my kids to use instead of giving as a gift.

I had to have this figure. He stands a couple inches taller than an average Funko POP toy. the detail is just perfect. I am very happy with this purchase. I ask that you make more figures cause the ones you've got available are awesome.
summary: I ask that you make more figures cause the ones you've got available are awesome.

reviewText:
Update: One year later, this toy is still surviving in my house of 4 rough kids. They are not delicate with their toys and this is still holding up just fine. Every child that comes to visit always checks this thing out first. Would buy again for sure.

Very cute toy, and it's held up well to my almost 2 year old playing with it. This toy makes a lot of rounds in my house, and has interested all my children; ages 1, 6, 9 and 12. I would buy it again.
summary: Very cute toy, and it's held up well to ...

reviewText: We used this from about 3 months onward (and are still using it at 10 months). An excellent alternative to filling up an entire bathtub, using the sink, or any of those expensive baby tubs. We love this product and highly recommend it.
Daughter loves stacking the cups and knocking them over. Also great to help learn colors.
summary: Also great to help learn colors

reviewText: Being a Saint Seiya Fan/Collector.  This product is nicely display on my shelf now.  This toy is for adults that appreciate toys.
summary: Saint Seiya brings back my childhood memories.

reviewText: Good service.  Purchased for some grandsons.  One daughter-in-law has already told me that he loves it.  He is almost 7 years old.  Also, his 3-year-old brother likes it.  The other grandson was all excited when he unwrapped it.  We don't see them as often and haven't heard any feedback.
Expensive, but strong and much enjoyed by the kids.
summary: but strong and much enjoyed by the kids
